Beyond the amazing fresh egg pasta with bolognese sauce and capreses salad, what really made our night was Elia - our waiter and son of the chef. He was very personal and accommodating to our kids. He even sang a personal happy birthday to our 10 yr old daughter. My only regret was that I didn't leave Elia more than my 20 percent tip. I guess my math skills were not so great after a few glasses of wine.
author: Lori B.

description:
Dined there on Friday with my friend. I got pasta and he got a pizza. 

Food was really good. The pizza was incredible. 

Service was excellent. 

The only thing I would ding it a star in was that the pasta dish was on the small side for the cost. 

Would visit again when I am in the city.
author: David H.

description:
We came here for dinner before the comedy club, based on yelp.
Restaurant was quaint and cozy, service was friendly, menu was limited with not much meat options, and a bit pricey at $20 per entree.
Yes, the pasta is homemade, and food is fresh but it was just alright for us. Nothing stood out. We ordered the truffle pizza and lasagna. I couldn't taste the truffle oil very much, and the pizza felt like a snack rather than a meal. I guess thin is in. Very thin crust, thin slices of salami, and thin red sauce with minimal cheese. Lasagna was bland and needed salt, and there was a bunch of oil around the dish which came from either the meat or cheese. We just weren't fans of the place, and thought maybe the seafood place next door might've been a better option. Definitely Hub was still hungry afterwards.
author: J S.

description:
Sweet little restaurant :) I came in with a couple of friends during some sort of street festival (just happened to be occurring at the time, we didn't know about it beforehand), and even with all the bustling outside, it felt cozy and fairly serene inside. Nice! Also, two of us (myself and a sea-gan) were vegetarians of one sort or another, and this place had plenty of things we could eat :)

I got the pizza with mushrooms, Mr. Piano got the pizza alla contadina (gorgonzola and pears), and our friends got a cheese-less pizza and one of the pizzas with the various meats on them (can't remember exactly which one). The mushroom pizza was delicious, as was the gorgonzola and pear pizza! I had asked, and while their pastas have eggs in it, their pizza dough does not (I have an egg allergy, plus we had our sea-gan friend), so that was great. The waitstaff was friendly and good about refilling our water glasses, as it was a warm day, so that was also fantastic.

While I don't expect to be in the neighborhood all that often, when I am, I will definitely be thinking about this place and their delicious pizzas :) Awesome!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Every girl has a best friend.

I have two: carbs and alkie.

Okie, maybe three since I rely on my spanx to hold in all the carbs and alkie I inhale.

BaoNecci is my new best friend. They have spectacular pizzas and wine. I'll even go as far as saying, they serve one of the best thin crust pizzas if not the best in SF. With over 20+ choices, BaoNecci beats my favorites: Tony's, Capo's, Delfina and Beretta. And, although the wine list is small, it's a quality selection. Get the chianti ($10/glass)!

Don't think about walking in here without reservations (listed under Opentable as "Baonecci Trattoria & Pizzeria") especially on a Thursday, Friday or Saturday night (they're closed on Sunday). BaoNecci seats about 35 people with 12 tables inside and 3 outside. We had reservations at 6 pm and midway through dinner, the dining room was packed and there was a wait. The ambiance is a bit kitschy but it adds to that authentic Italian feel http://bit.ly/14htGwt. 

There were so many choices so after perusing the menu for some time, we decided to start with the Burrata Salad ($12.95): http://bit.ly/14cbhkg. I would skip this next time as the burrata lacked that quintessential silky, buttery texture and was too watery in the center. I wished heirloom tomatoes were used since they're more robust in flavor and would have given this salad more oomph. 

I opted for the Contadina w/ Mozzarella, Parmigiano, Gorgonzola & Pears Pizza ($16.95): http://bit.ly/13iDBlR. I added proscuitto for an additional $4. Almost too pretty to eat, the blistery, crackly crust was deliciously crunchy . I normally hate pizza crusts but these were addictingly good. If you're a sweet and savory flavor whore, you will LOVE this pizza. The melange of salty proscuitto, rich and pungent cheeses along with the crisp, sweet ribbons of pear were ridiculously good. I inhaled the entire pizza but didn't feel grossly bloated afterwards because it was light.

My friend ordered the Salamino E Salsiccia Pizza w/ Fresh Tomato, Mozzarella, Sausage & Pepperoni ($15.95): http://bit.ly/YgLoyJ. A solid choice if you like something meaty and rich. This would make the ultimate drunk food after happy hour nearby as it will soak up all the copious amounts of booze you've downed.

We didn't have room for dessert but I have my eye on that Nutella Dessert Pizza the next time I come. 

Service was equally as fantastic as the food. The food was a solid 4.5 stars but the service boosts my rating to 5. The entire Italian accented staff was warm, charming, and attentive. I was waiting for my friend to arrive and one of the waiters passed by several times to check on me. He probably felt bad thinking I got stood up on date.

Don't be a lush like me and drink on a empty stomach. Just half a glass of the chianti made me tipsy while waiting for my friend. I missed the [one] step to the bathroom and nearly face planted...in flats! It's a good thing I didn't, otherwise crutches would be my ONLY best friend for the next 6 weeks. =X
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Wait, how have I never written a review for this place? I admittedly haven't been here in a couple years...but this is my faaavorite pizza place. Evar. I get the same thing every time - La Contadina (prosciutto pear) and the nutella and fruit dessert pizza. I'm overdue for a visit, maybe I'll branch out this time. I'm sure everything else is equally fantastic.
author: Jennifer H.

description: This place has very good food, and authentic. Italian family owned and run. You will be greeted by one of them at the door.  I'm Italian and have been to several Italian restaurants where they pledge their authenticity; this was one of the best.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This is like going back to Italy even through I've never been to Italy. The servers are great and have an Italian accent. 

It's a small little place where you have to go through the kitchen to get to the bathroom. The mom is in the kitchen making all this great food. 

The Stefania's salad was so good and large. It big enough to share with someone. The thin crust pizza is the best I have ever had. It's so good... I had the La Contadina with green pear slices and the Salsiccia E Salami. I would recommend both. My son had the Meat Lasagna and I have never tasted anything like this. So good. 
Can't wait for my next visit here so I can visit this place again. The BEST
author: Doug T.

description: super duper thin crust pizzas!! everything is made in house as it's a family run business. for pizzas, we got the margarita, funghi, and one with meat, as well as the pasta bolognese. the pasta was slightly too salty for my liking. pizzas were good, and single serving, but i guess i wanted more crust and bite... we also got a bottle of chianti that was very young n bright. service is fast n attentive. would i come back again voluntarily..? probs not...
author: Christina L.

description:
Baonecci is one of those full on Italian restaurants you'll find in San Francisco. It's of a decent size, in a hilly location in Little Italy. The food there has a rich, tomato sauce, most of it anyways, and the bread is the heavenly type of good! They have an odd addition of pizzas, for most are with prosciutto, not that I'm complaining. It's great, as is the pasta, but if you've been to a magnificent Italian restaurant, this is really comparable. The portions are all for just a single person, definitely not any more. 

My experience there wasn't exactly splendid, but my opinion was that the restaurant and the food were above average. My cousin was visiting from Europe, along with her daughter, who complained enormously about the food, for silly reasons. Gross prosciutto, too much sauce, or too little sauce, but no. They weren't reasonable. Baonecci is a great, homey restaurant you should definitely try out.
author: Georgiana P.

description:
Great pizza and homemade pastas. Wish they had a Caesar salad and that would complete all my Italian needs. They specialize in cracker thin pizzas which I absolutely love. Flavors are very fresh.

My favorites are the anchovy and caper pizza and tomato and garlic pasta. Honestly, I don't think you could go wrong with anything here.

Been here twice and haven't had a problem getting in. Definitely recommend if you'd like to try something a little bit different.
author: Stine H.

description: The food is absolutely delicious!!!  So happy we found this place. I highly recommend the pizza and lasagna.  Authentic Italian. Yummy!!!!
author: Stella D.

description:
When I did a pizza search on yelp one day I came across Caffe BaoNecci and noticed how they claimed to be the first thin crust pizza in San Francisco.  This I had to see firsthand because I have become very intrigued with the concept of extremely paper thin crust pizzas ever since I had the thin crust pizza at Palomino.

Came by for lunch and I was their first customer of the day.  So for me, service was pretty much on point.  They have a wide selection of pizzas, from the classics like Margherita and Quattro Stagioni, along with their specialty pizzas such as the Monte Blanco and the Porca.  But for this occaision, I decided to splurge and go for the Truffle Salame.

Truffle Salame Pizza (http://bit.ly/1137v93) - San Marzano Tomato, Fresh Mozzarella, Truffle Salame, Truffle Oil, Arugala.

HEAVEN!!!  So much flavor going on with the Truffle Oil and Truffle Salami.  The Arugala helped balance out the flavor.  And despite its thinness, the crust was very good as well.  In the great words of George Takei (even though it's meant for something else), OH MYYYY!  Best pizza I've ever eaten!  And that's saying a lot because I've had my share of good pies and bad pies.  Or maybe I'm just a sucker for really thin crust pizza.  Just look at how thin this slice is (http://bit.ly/TrwG2r).  When it comes to really thin crust pizzas, Baonecci takes the prize!

Even though this was my only visit, I'm already sold on coming here more often to try their other pizzas and menu items.  Granted, I wouldn't recommend the place if you're expecting to load up on some fat slices of pizza.  You can go to Seniore's,  Nizario's, or even nearby Golden Boy Pizza for that.  But if you're looking for the best tasting pizzas around, I would definitely recommend Baonecci all the way!
author: Rodney H.

description:
Overrated place with overpriced pizza.  

Even though it is family run, and they are known for their flat bread, thinly crusted pizza, the pizza they served us, was BURNT!  Not okay!  Their pizza was quite bland too!  Not much flavor to it and too oily!  Ugh.

Picture of burnt pizza:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gtIud2JPu_tW3LMldEOUaw?select=QtlShKepseJBE2zHdvWrww#QtlShKepseJBE2zHdvWrww

Service was below par!  We had to ask for their complimentary bread instead of them serving it to us before the meal.  Pretty sluggish place with waiters watching the TV instead of serving the customers.

My friend and I are very unsatisfied with the dining experience.  You're only paying for the ambiance and decor to this Italian restaurant.  Other than that, spend your money on other flavorful, tasty pizza dining restaurants around the block!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Loved our meal here! Pizzas were wonderful with perfect cracker thin crust. Walter is a great host and we will be back!
author: Greg L.

description: On Fri evening around 7:30 we were greeted without smile and then first thing we heard is "Sorry, no table tonight.". So I asked "Why?" And then response was "all tables reserved until 9 pm. You can check open table." So I did and there was a reservation available for group of 4 at 8 pm. I could have reserved the table but I decided not to at uninviting place. Besides, there are many options nearby. We ended up eating at Il Casaro as it doesn't take any reservations and the wait time was under 30 minutes. It was one of the best Burrata and Pizza Margharita I have ever had. No one wants to spend Fri evening in a hole in the wall with rude and uncourteous staff.
author: C S.

description:
My wife and I have been here a few times for dinner, and it's always been fantastic. The bolognese in particular is incredible. 

I highly recommend getting reservations, though, especially on the weekend. It's a tiny little place, and it fills up very quickly.
author: David K.

description: Food was ok but nothing special. I expect more in an area with so many Italian options.
author: Ellie G.

description: Perfetto! This place has the most authentic pizza in the Bay Area, period!
author: Antonio S.

description: looking for late night eats and found Bao Necci to be delightful. thin crust pizza with gorgonzola and shaved pears was delicious. to finish off the meal, the cannoli was perfectly sweet with a great crunchy shell. customer service was extreme friendly. made you feel welcome. well worth the visit.
author: steve c.

description: I am stunned by the 5 star reviews of this place, but maybe that's because this is in Little Italy and most of the reviews are from tourists? The place is really cute and intimate and I found the man that seated us (bus boy) to be very friendly. However after that, the one waiter looked us and almost scoffed at us (both the only minorities in the restaurant, and I NEVER play this card), and just threw our menus on the table without a word.  He never returned....Thank goodness for the owner (I think) who finally came over to help us and was very friendly.  The 3 stars are for the waiter and the quality of the food, unfortunately.  We ordered the bruschetta to start, which was excellent, so we had high hopes for our pasta dishes.  We ordered the Tagliatelle All Arrabiatta, and the sauce was AMAZING, but the pasta  was overcooked and not al dente as I have grown to expect from high quality Italian restaurants.  We also ordered the Tagliatelle Alla Bolognese, which was seriously lacking in flavor and sauce.  It was basically just the meat without sauce or flavor, and again, the pasta was overcooked.  Given that there are so many restaurants to try in the city, I probably won't be back.
author: Arthi N.

description:
We read the other reviews and thought we'd give this place a try. This place was ok at best. It's not the place to eat if you want dishes with meat in them. The dishes with meat are limited to a lasagna with meat sauce and a few pizzas and calzones with meat toppings. 

Our party got some dishes to share so that we could try different menu items. The lasagna and the eggplant parmesan were very good. The Quatro Formaggio pizza was not good at all. It was paper thin and did not have a very good flavor. It didn't even smell very good. On the plus side, they did take the pizza off of the bill. 

The service was not good either. Once our order was taken and our food was dropped off, we didn't see our server for a very long time.  We were hungry from walking around the city, but didn't get any bread until our meals came. The bread was delish! 

The food came out in a reasonable amount of time, however our water glasses were empty for the majority of the meal and no one ever came to see if we liked our food or if we needed anything, like WATER! It took a long time to get our server to bring our check. 

Bottom line, I would go else where. There was an Italian restaurant next door that looked way better called Sodini's. They've been in business since 1918...enough said!
author: Karen S.

description:
Based on a pick up order since the place was packed, and I was huuuuuungry.

Canneloni = not too sweet but oh so delicious. I did not agree too much with the cherry tho it reminded me too much of robitussin. I prefer those kind of cherries in my old fashion.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=c-sb7Rue56e503roUnE7BA&userid=0ZeOlR7vRx1GkEjXkcBlFg

Bruschetta = oh so so delicious. I did however sprinkled red chili pepper and parnesan on top to enhance the flavor.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=5w8EAKDDZ28iMhet6h7FTg&userid=0ZeOlR7vRx1GkEjXkcBlFg

First of let me just say that I love thin crust. This place has the best! The texture reminds me of lavash bread when it is crisped up in the oven. Toppings are adequate enough to taste the flavors. Nothing is over powered. I do admit though that my hubs and I finished both pizzas since they were so light. 

Cuatro stagaloni = this was a great option especiallly if you are indecisive. The toppings pair well with one another.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=RIJS7670RBtgZKI--GJF2g&userid=0ZeOlR7vRx1GkEjXkcBlFg

Salamino e salciccia = simple but elegant in taste. What more can I say?
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=157j61F4Lp3bVN7Scg9onQ&userid=0ZeOlR7vRx1GkEjXkcBlFg
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
When I go out to eat, I like food which tastes good and is a decent value.  My girlfriend and I had a calzone ($22) and eggplant Parmesan ($18),  When I compare the calzone to Pizza My Heart's, the Baonecci comes up lacking . . . big time.  It wasn't bad.  It just wasn't all that flavorful and the crust was too thin for my liking.  Maybe this is "authentic" Italian food (there were some Italian speaking diners eating there when we were there)  and, if so, I don't care for "authentic" Italian food.  The crust on the calzone here was thin and crispy.  Sort of like a saltine, but without the salt.  My girlfriend did enjoy her eggplant Parmesan.  I tasted it and it was okay. The meal came with nothing else.  Not even bread.  A glass of Chianti was $11 and there was sediment in the glass of wine.  I would rather go to a pizzeria and get a New York style pizza or calzone than spend what I did here. 
After seeing the extremely thin crust for the pizza for the woman at the table next to us, I know that I would never buy a pizza here.  Just a few doors down there was a line out the door for pizza by the slice.  
The service was good and friendly too.  Even though the food was just okay, I did leave a nice tip for the server(s).
So, I am not saying this is not a good restaurant.  I am saying that I would prefer to eat elsewhere going forward.
author: The Sanity Cruze R.

description:
LOVED.

Started out with tuna starter. Fresh, well seasoned. It came with strange bread though. It'd be easier to eat with something else.

The service was beyond excellent.

Food...oh...I had the cannelloni, friend had the lasagna. The homemade noodles were so creamy, they just melt in your mouth. I never order stuffed pasta, but I just had to, and didn't regret it. Nor did I feel disgustingly full afterwards. It was perfect.

We had an excellent time.
author: Amy O.

description: This restaurant is a perfection in North Beach.  Very friendly service, excellent sauces on delicious homemade pastas.  Amongst all the great neighborhood competitors, Baonecci stands out as a real gem!
author: Michael T.

description: The pizza and calzone were amazing. Closest thing to real Italian pizzas have had since studying abroad in Italy. We also got the salad with bureaus and the cheese was unbelievably fresh.
author: Jaime R.

description:
Baonecci serves the best pizza I have ever had. I loved the ultrathin crust with just the right amounts of sauce and toppings. I was glad to be able to tell them it was the best pizza I'd ever eaten. And my friends know that dairy free gluten free me ate plenty of it "back in the day" - and this was a one-time special occasion treat. WORTH IT!

Pasta dishes are beautiful and so was the antipasti platter. This is a small, family owned restaurant serving its food with love and care. All the wait staff are excellent and the owner/mom/cook is a beautiful lady. Do not, please, pay any attention to the foolish people who are so picky, mean and evil leaving vicious Yelp comments because they have nothing better to do with their lives. We were looking for the best Italian food in North Beach, and while there are so many excellent restaurants and friendly people, Baonecci is it. Real Italian food is extremely delicious and varied. So, this isn't the spaghetti & meatballs type of place, it is Lucchese-style - Tuscan.
author: Amy Sterling C.

description: I can't believe this place. Unbelievable. The pizza was amazing....the best I've had since....well since I was on my honeymoon in Italy. Light, rich, flavorful and delicious. We'll definitely be back!
author: Dia J.

description:
We initially intended to dine at a nearby restaurant, but a twist of fate brought us here, which we were very glad. It's a small restaurant with very cozy ambient. The minimal decorations include a humongous wooden pizza scoop, which is pretty cool.  

We ordered a Lasagna Casereccia and Cigniala Pizza. Wife's lasagna was excellent. The meat sauce is flavorful and well balanced. It's worth noting that the lasagna is different from the others that it uses only Parmesan cheese and bechamel sauce. 

My pizza was great!! It has just the right amount of cheese (mozzarella)  and san marino tomato sauce (that expensive good stuff). Toppings include mushroom and wild boar salami. The pizza crust is probably the best part. It's lightly charred, paper thin, and crispy...almost like a cracker. So, every bite was crispy, full of various flavors from the ingredients and char. I especially love the gaminess of the wild boar salami. However, due to it's thickness, don't let the pizza sits too long or it will get soggy. 

Overall, I'd rate our experience as 4.5 stars and I couldn't find any fault with our experience. Wife and I noted the two good looking young Italian servers (they look like brothers and could be the owner's sons) who are friendly and always smiling. Because of that, I think I'd bump the review up to a 5 stars :-)
author: Kin N.

description: Snag a seat at the bar to eat delicious pizzas without a reservation. Pizzas are on the pricier side, but are oh so good. Thin pizzas with high quality ingredients like prosciutto and other Italian meats , add mascarpone and you are good to go. This establishment is run by an Italian family that really knows their food.
author: Patty O.

description: Their pizza's are soooo good. We've eaten in the restaurant but also pulled the car outside and ran in to pick up carry out when we can't get a table. I'm sad they're not open on Sundays.
author: Char M.

description: Small, intimate restaurant with outdated decor. We ordered the pizza with sausage and pepperoni. The sauce, cheese, and meats were definitely of a higher quality and delicious, but the pizza was so thin and crisp it's basically like eating a cracker (or described as like "a communion wafer" by my dinner date). 6 slices for $19. Eh. We felt unmotivated to try anything else or stick around for dessert.
author: Natasha P.

description:
I have only been here twice but both times were exceptional.  The homemade pasta is very good and alone worth a trip.  The best time to visit is between lunch and diner ~ otherwise you had better have a reservation, OR do what we do and eat at their small bar.  This is not the Olive Garden so don't expect that kind of "Italian" food...

LOL, I do not post pictures of my food because I think that is the most pretentious thing you can do in a fine restaurant!  Plus, most pictures do not do good food justice!
author: John M.

description: Went here for the first time last night with some friends. They were super accommodating and let us in even though their kitchen was about to close. Service was prompt and friendly. Pizzas were delicious, I just wish they were bigger!!
author: Christine E.

description:
In town visiting my best friend, plus helping move our son into a new apartment with his fiancée. We've been to Italy, and appreciate finding the "real thing." The Gambaccini family offer the real thing at their trattoria. Fantastic pizza, delightful pasta, comprehensive wine list. Service that is friendly, but without hovering. We were allowed to enjoy our time with friends, conversation, and the wine at our own pace. We ate family style, sharing plates: Taglierino di Formaggi, pizze Diavola e Funghi, Eggplant Parmigiana alla Stefania, Tagliatelle all' Arrabbiata, plus two bottles of Chianti Montellori Rosso. Delizioso! Elia, one of the owners' two sons, took very good care of us, making recommendations, checking in on us from time to time, and ensuring we had all we needed. He wished my AS Roma team good luck against Juve as we left, having noticed my "No Totti, No Party" t-shirt. Forza Roma!

Ci torneremo, garantito. Grazie mille, Elia.
author: Jim B.

description:
There is a god, and her name is Stefania Gambaccini.

This is probably my favorite restaurant in all of the Bay Area (not counting fine dining, which is a different ballgame). I've been there at least five times, and I've been wowed each and every time.

Listen, first thing's first--this is Luccan fare, not Neapolitan pizza, so you can't use the Margherita as your measuring stick. That would be like ordering Chicken Tikka Masala at Saravana Bhavan, silly!

Here are some things we got on our most recent visit:

***TAGLIERE ANTIPASTO TOSCANO - Prosciutto Parma, Salame, Coppa, mortadella, Pecorino cheese

Yummy cured meats & pecorino garnished with caperberries. Hard to go wrong when you're using the freshest of ingredients. A delightful beginning.

***LASAGNA - Bolognese meat sauce, parmigiano, bechamel

Walter Gambaccini & son Elia separately recommended this to us, but I can't say that I was completely enthralled with their take on it, because frankly lasagna is lasagna. Each layer of dough was meaty and fresh, though and the cheese on top was noticeably artisanal. But I like gooey, moist, and light, and this was slightly dry and a bit heavy.

***MONTE BIANCO - San marsano tomatoes, fresh mozzarella, prosciutto parma, scoop of mascarpone cheese

We're treading on sacred ground here, so please take your hat off. As simple as it sounds, this thin crust pizza is baked to a perfect crispiness, and the ingredients are just top notch. The mozzarella provides the body and texture, but it's not overwhelming, instead painfully fresh & perfectly mild, for with BaoNecci pizzas, the cheese is just a vehicle to deliver the other goodies. That prosciutto melts in your mouth with a godly level of saltiness, and that mascarpone, oh glorious mascarpone--you are as sweet, thick, & creamy as a cherub! I hereby would like to request that I be buried in a coffin filled with sweetened mascarpone (catered by BaoNecci of course).

***TRUFFLE SALAME - San marzano tomato, fresh mozzarella, truffle salame, truffle oil, arugola

Keep your voice down, reciting this holy script of ingredients is a religious exercise. The truffle salame is dreamily rich, the arugola provides those crucial bitter accents and leafiness, and that truffle oil, the fragrance emanating therefrom fills the entire kitchen. I could IV this liquid gold into my veins and survive on its sustenance alone! These two pizzas are BaoNecci's secret weapons--one bite and you'll be forever prostituting yourself out for another.

***CANNOLI

I was extremely disappointed that the Affogato Chocolate Tartufo was sold out. This is BaoNecci's signature dessert, described as chocolate in the shape of a truffle (the fungi variety) and filled with custard. So we went with the cannoli. The plating was absolutely gorgeous with a preserved cherry as garnish. The cannoli itself was solid, but was just missing something--the filling had that perfect consistency, but it wasn't quite sweet enough, and the pastry shell lacked that "Step aside, I was just deep-fried!" punch in the face. It was solid though. Next time that Tartufo is mine!

ALL IN ALL:

The gods fated that I would happen upon BaoNecci--it was predestined. How else could you explain it?

By the way, the Gambaccini sons (Elia & Filippo), who happen to be waiters here, have perfectly chiseled noses and chins. Was that my heart that just fluttered? *blushes* http://www.theofficequotes.com/season-6/gossip/quote_2760
author: Elliott D.

description:
I have been trying to go to Baoecci for a few months now. Every time I tried, there was at least an hour wait. I tried it again a couple of days ago and it was indeed more of the same thing. I ended up waiting over one hour and a half.

Once we finally got the table, I enjoyed every minute of my experience! We were seated inside, we had a very nice server and the food was amazing. To drink, we ordered a bottle of Italian white white wine (by the way, the place is famous for their extensive wine list). Make sure you ask to get the best recommendation.

As a starter, we had the Antipesto de Breasola. As a main we had the Ortolana pizza, which we decided to share. The pizza was delicious, and more than enough for two people. 

Once we were done, no one rushed us to leave. The staff took their time clearing the table and bringing the check, which I really appreciated. Being such a busy restaurant you would expect them to rush you out the door as soon as you're finished, but not at Baenecci's

Overall, worth the wait, I would do it again in a heart beat!
author: Pablo R.

description: One of the best lasagna I've ever had! A must try. Great service and atmosphere along with the great service!
author: Humberto B.

description:
We went to this place after reading great review. It was 5pm and there were only six customers. There were many empty tables. There were six of us. 

I understand Italian as we lived there for three years. Simply put we were not given a table because we have too many children (four kids.) We asked one guy when would be the earliest possible time to make a reservation.  The waiter was speaking in Italian to another waiter that he should not give a table to us because of our "bambini."  Quite a disappointment as we could not even try their foods. 

Mika Watanabe
author: M. W.

description: Loved the feeling of a "mom and pap restaurant", where mom Stefania is actually making you authentic Tuscan meals and deserts.
author: Victoria G.

description: Oh wow, such a classic street.  Just having people talking italian during dinner made it better.   We order the Salumii and sausage pizza ,  high quality meats with crispy crust.  The margarita was brilliant, perfect blistering and we added spicy sauce to compliment the pizza.
author: Ross W.

description:
I was in SF for a weekend with my friends and we were craving pizza, but Tony Pizza had a 45 minute or more wait and Golden Boy was cash only and not a sit down style restaurant. We were lucky to find BaoNecci and were seated immediately. 

I ordered the Truffle Salame and was pleasantly surprised. My friends ordered Salamino E Salsiccia and Salsiccia e Taleggio pizzas but we all shared and agreed the Truffle Salame was the winner of the night.  The truffle flavor really made the pizza stand out from the other 2 we had.  My friends didn't like that the pizzas were so thin, although this is an Italian style, but I thought the thickness was fine, it just didn't look as appealing as other thin crust Italian style pizza I've had before. We each also ordered wine and beer.  The total for each of us was around $30 each which is a little steeper than we would've liked considering the pizzas were truly personal sized and weren't on par to what we were expecting.  I prefer Delfina in the Mission District, they have a better quality pizza (among other dishes).  

Service was also a little spotty, we waited at least 20 minutes to get the attention of a waiter to order.  When we turned around we saw that a party that was seated after us had already ordered and gotten a bread basket, which we never got.  When we wanted more water, again it was a challenge to get a waiter's attention. However, when we wanted to get our check there was no problem there, they got our check to us immediately.

So, yes, I would recommend the Truffle Salame and give BaoNecci a try maybe try other items on their menu too.  I would give 4 stars to the pizza alone, but the unfortunate service and unpleasant experience of my friends inclines me to deduct a star.
author: Tiffany V.

description: It was around 5 on a Thursday nite, and I picked this place online based on the fact that it looked intimate, and likely not a zoo on the main drag of North Beach. We'd been moving all day, and I wanted to treat my fiancé to something relaxing and rustic. We made the right choice here, the food was SO. GOOD. Serious. We started with the eggplant parm appetizer, and it was delicious. I had mushroom tortellini, and he had the pasta with meat sauce. Loved them both, we will be back asap. Service was awesome, laid back and attentive. We lucked out without a reservation, but the place filled up completely within ten minutes of sitting down. Try this place, it's a great find.
author: Kayla P.

description:
I can't speak to the pasta, but the pizzas are amazing!  If you like thin crust and premium meats then give this place a try! 

We had the maremma maiala and the truffle salame - the sausage was the star of the first pizze and the arugula - salame - truffle trio is worth a repeat visit itself.  

Wine selection is on par, the decor is a bit dated, the service is ok...come for the pizza...period.
author: Dan N.

description: OMG--don't think about it just go.  Best pizza ever. Try the pizza with mascerpone, and the truffle pizza, then have the pear pizza( adult dessert) and Nutella pizza (kids dessert)!
author: Kerrie S.

description:
Come for the food, leave for the service!

We came in and were seated pretty quickly, ordered within 2-3 minutes, food came out and was decent (3.5 stars) but Spicy. Unfortunately my water was never refilled once, kind of just rushed in and out. 

Maybe grab a slice of the pizza in the window 2 doors east and call it a day!
author: Stu P.

description:
Boanecci is a hidden gem, an unassuming, charming little restaurant that you may miss if you blink.

This family-run place will transport you to Italy. It has the best uber-thin crust pizza in San Francisco. The dough is perfectly cracker crisp; made from San Marzano tomatoes, the sauce is perfect; whichever you choose, the toppings are fresh and tasty.  With shredded Romaine and other lettuces, the insalta Baonecci is delicious.

Pair your dinner with a selection from the mostly Italian wine list and you will transport yourself to Italia.
author: CJ G.

description: We stopped in for lunch and had a wonderful meal.  This restaurant makes its own pasta and we could tell in the pasta dishes that we had.   The TV in the dining room features an Italian channel so you know this is real Italian.
author: Michael O.

description: Amazing food and wine!! The service was great and we had an amazing pizza and pasta! The owner was really sweet and the staff you can tell really enjoy their work. All and all a great experience and food! Make a reservation as it is busy we sat at the bar with no wait and enjoyed that too!
author: Stacey S.

description:
This place has the best lasagna I have ever had. Seems to be a family run business.
It is small, but we arrived when it opened for dinner at 5pm so we were able to get a table without a reservation. Everyone else in my family ordered the various pizzas.  The pizza is also delicious (I had a few pieces that the family could not finish) and everything seems to be made fresh and on hand at the restaurant.
The pizza crust is "super thin crust" and can get expensive since the menu and the waiter claim that each pizza is a "single serving" pizza. (So 3 in our family ordered 3 pizzas) Although the pizzas are not huge- one pizza can be split between two medium size eaters pretty easily; which could save you some money.
Definitely worth a stop to eat some good home cooked Italian food when visiting the San Francisco area, particulary if you are staying near "little Italy".
author: John K.

description:
I've eaten here twice now and both times it was excellent. I managed to get in without a reservation and sat at the bar, which is perfect because the owner gives great service at the bar!
Everything is homemade and yummy; pizza, pasta and lasagna are all to die for. 
The ambiance is quaint and authentic, great all around.
author: Alli K.

description: This was the best Italian food I have found on the West Coast. The pizza was incredible, very clean, simple, and fresh. Atmosphere was quintessential small cafe--waiters are a bit aloof, but the food makes up for it. Worth the wait when we arrived early for our reservation. Not a place you should miss if you live in SF or want to take your loved one for a special date night.
author: Alana A.

description: We ordered bruschetta for anti pasti, truffle salami pizza with arugula, the sausage & onion pizza, tiramisu for dessert, and they were all excellent except for the tiramisu. The tiramisu is not anything special but the pizzas were delicious. The crust was thin and crispy. It was perfect. At first we were surprised when we saw the price for each pizza, they were like $18 each and we thought they were expensive, but since we were already seated and hungry we just went ahead and took our chances. The pizza is good for only one person so it is quite expensive for one pizza but let me tell you this, it was worth it!! Don't let the price stop you from eating there. As a side note, we did not wait long to be seated as we agreed to eat outside the restaurant.
author: Rowena R.

description: This meal was fantastic! Much better than we expected it to be. We ordered the pizza bufalina and the pizza baonecci which were both incredible. Though the bufalina is obviously a very simple dish, it was incredible well done and we were very impressed. I highly recommend it if you are in the mood for Italian. The service was quick and the waiters were cordial and nice. The atmosphere is cozy and very pleasant.
author: Christiane S.

description:
Note: Even if you use OpenTable to make reservations, they want you to call at 3 PM on the day of your reservation to confirm.

BaoNecci specializes in thin-style, cracker-crisp pizza that is common to Rome.  It's much crispier than the Neopolitan style, which can get soggy.  According to various sources of authority, Baonecci has the best Roman pizza in San Francisco, so I had to try it out.  The pizza is excellent, and lives up to the hype.  I had the "Salamino piccante e Salsiccia": San marzano tomato sauce, mozzarella, Italian sausage, and calabrese Salame ($18.95): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baonecci-restaurant-san-francisco?select=e2oLJIQt18OD0inGpmMuyw#e2oLJIQt18OD0inGpmMuyw

It's very light and crisp, with just a bit of softness in the center.  Actually, I think i may prefer the pesto/salame pizza at Donato Enoteca in Redwood City, which has just a bit more chew throughout, and a bit less soft in the center: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/donato-enoteca-redwood-city?select=Y_DzLWvFP3NkuZpg-EcC1Q#Dt-HpZEhF0Jhzu9--qOqRQ

I also had the Tiramisu ($6.95), which is above average: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baonecci-restaurant-san-francisco?select=e2oLJIQt18OD0inGpmMuyw#B_o8l60PFQKXx4N6nStzkw

It has 3 distinct layers: mousse on top, a center of soaked lady fingers, and a bottom that is creamy.  Each layer had good flavor and texture: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/baonecci-restaurant-san-francisco?select=e2oLJIQt18OD0inGpmMuyw#J6MGnaO7xun9OBmk-WKxUg

One note: in the Yelp photos you will see a Focaccia di Recco, which looks really good.  I did not find it on the menu.
author: Scott F.

description:
Wowza! I had, arguably, the most inventive pizza ever here. The pizza Contadina has three cheeses (gorgonzola, mozzarella and parmesan) and topped with, get this, thinly sliced pears!! The flavors melt together perfectly -- salty and melty-ness of the cheeses and the sweet and slight crunch of the pears. Oh heaven!! And did I mention the crust did not go limpy? It was the thinnest pizza crust that I've ever witnessed and I've had pizza in Italy.

My boyfriend had the calzone, which I tried a bit. The dough is made from the same thin pizza dough so it's light. The filling consisted of ricotta, ham and mushrooms and the sauce came in a separate little cup. The sauce was super fresh and complemented the calzone without overwhelming the flavors of the filling.

Caffe BaoNecci is one of the gems of North Beach. It's family ran and the people were helpful and friendly. I will definitely be back to try the other pies. Glad that places like this still exist in the neighborhood.
author: Alice W.

description:
The most authentic pizza I have ever had in my life! This place is family run and owned (and they speak Italian to each other- which added to the charm of this restaurant).  If you are in North Beach, you MUST try this place!  

Initially I was planning on going to Tony's Pizza but the wait was outrageous (1.5 hour on a Sunday at 4:30).  I am so happy that I stumbled across this place (which is only 1 block away from Tony's Pizza).  

We ordered the Caprese Salad and 2 pizzas.  It was the right amount for 2 people.  Extremely fresh and authentic ingredients.  I can't remember the names of the pizzas we ordered, but one had truffle oil and the other one was under the "meat" pizza options.  Couldn't have been any more pleased with our dinner.  

The pizza crust is very thin- paper/cracker like thin- which is delish! You will leave this place feeling not too full, but "just right".  Each pizza runs around $20- but it is completely worth it!

5 stars for sure.  Will most definitely take my friends from out of town here!!
author: Anna G.

description:
Oh god! I think I died and went to heaven!

Okay. So I did have this place bookmarked based on all the rave reviews (and partially on a whim) and since it was in walking distance from our hotel, we decided to go to dinner here on our first night in San Francisco. 

We started with the Caesar Salad which was tasty. Peppery. Light. Great. But nothing that I would need to have. You can skip this and not miss anything if you're familiar with a good Caesar. (Save this and get another pizza!)

Now... the pizza! We decided on the Cotto e Funghi. I cannot even begin to say how much I love this pizza. I was a bit put off when they first brought it out since the prosciutto basically covered the pizza... but it was amazing. Best pizza I've ever had in my life! The cheese. Amazing. The mushrooms. Fresh. Tasty. Delicious. The prosciutto. The best I've ever had. Seriously. Amazingly tasty. 

Also, I usually don't like thin pizza... but this one has changed my mind completely. It's amazing. AMAZING. Aromatic. A bit crispy. Delicious. 

Great service. Quick. Friendly. Family Owned.

To use the restroom, you have to walk through the kitchen. It was very clean. Love it when restaurants do this. I saw the woman baking our delicious pizzas! I had to tell her how much I loved the pizza (which is something I rarely do!) 

I wish I would have taken one to go on the way home and came here every other night! 

I'm in love! I only wish there was one in Los Angeles or anywhere closer. Do they ship?! hahaha! I'm serious!

Next time I'm in San Francisco, I will definitely be back!
author: Sam L.

description: Soooo good! The spicy pasta was delicious and actually had a kick. Loved the pizza. Amazing ambiance. Didn't feel rushed.
author: Amit S.

description:
I REALLY liked this place.

We started with the burratta salad and it was great, fresh, and a nice warm up for the pizza.

For pizza, we got Salamino pizza and the Monte Bianco. I loved both, but the Monte Bianco more, and my boyfriend liked the other more :)

We had just the right amount of food and a wonderful time!
author: Alexandra W.

description: Right next to golden boy pizza but exponentially better. Authentic Italians food.  Pizza as you expect from Italy.  The staff also is straight from Italy and super friendly and nice.  Everything is exceptionally good. Worth the wait.  Will definitely be back.
author: Susannah K.

description: Most people know I come from a long background of pizza. I am deemed a pizza enthusiast. Came across this gem through Yelp, so glad that I did. Customized my pizza today: had the spicy marinara sauce with herbs, olive oil, and garlic. I also topped it with fresh arugula, shaved Parmesan, and truffle oil. It was oh so amazing!!! I am sad now, Bc I will crave something so far way. This will unquestionably be a place I will frequent anytime I'm in town.
author: Lana K.

description:
hubs and I had a rare SF date night and decided to go to Tony's Pizza.  There was an hour wait so we were forced to Yelp the area and find a different pizza place.
that's how we got here.
came in and was asked if we have reservations.  the server was hesitant at first when we told him we don't which I thought was odd considering the place is practically empty.

we ordered caprese salad: very bland.  the olive oil is almost non existent, no seasoning, the cheese was okay but the tomatoes were really bad.  In my opinion, for a salad as simple as this, if one of the main ingredients (tomatoes) is not up to par... it shouldn't be offered in the menu at all. 
the free bread they gave us: pieces of pizza crust.  good but I didn't see the point of offering it since we're ordering more pizza.
hubs and I shared the quattro pizza... also disappointing despite of good reviews.  the crust was soggy, didn't really understand the point of separating the 4 bland ingredients.  

the service was oh-kay.

at the end of the dinner: we wondered why this place had great reviews.  being in an area where there are tons of italian restaurant, it will be hard for us to find a reason to come back here.
author: Learnee L.

description:
Possibly the best pizza I've ever eaten ever! The crust was perfect: thin, crispy, chewy, flavorful. I can't remember or pronounce any of the names, but we had the anchovy pizza with capers. The combination worked very well, and the amounts of the ingredients were just right. 

My hubby and I were very hungry, so one pizza was not enough to fill us (they are on the smaller side), and we also ordered the lasagna (after overhearing the table next to us say that the lasagna was a must!). The lasagna had very thin layers of filling, which made the flavors more delicate. Not heavy and overwhelming at all. 

I wish we could've tried more! The prosciutto pizza with the glob of mascarpone cheese looked unbelievably delicious (table next to us got it). The server told that couple to spread the cheese onto the slices as you eat them. yum.....

We didn't have a reservation, but they accommodated us anyway, and the service was excellent! The space is small, so if you want to come at a busy time, a reservation might be prudent.
author: NY C.

description: 2 words. EAT HERE!!!!! The truffled salami pizza may be the best thing I have eaten. I've literally have been dreaming about since my last SF visit.... Wonder if they deliver to Southern California?
author: Christie P.

description:
This place is run by an Italian family from Lucca so I went in with high expectations.  However, the menu turned out to be just pretty standard Italian fair (pizzas, lasagnas, pasta) without any tint of Tuscan influence.  At least they don't have stupid fettuccine Alfredo, which is an invention for Americans.

I ordered pasta con funghi porcini.  Unfortunately, the pasta was overcooked (not al dente) and most of the mushrooms were not porcini.  I should have known.  $18 is really too cheap for it.

My table mates ordered various pizzas and they look good, but I did not try them.  However, that's what I would order next time, if I happen to be in the area.
author: Will T.

description:
What a great surprise this little Gem is. All the other Italian places were an hour plus wait. Nothing is worth that long a wait. 
Everything here is in house made from the pasta to the Tiramisu. Lasagna and Cannelloni were excellent. Bread baked in house as well. Try the Brochette. Highly recommended.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I don't hand out 5-stars often but this review is well deserved. Made a reservation for 4 on a Friday back in July. Got there before the other party and had a drink at the bar before being seated. No wait, our table was ready when the other party arrived. 

The wine and beer list is 90% Italian but you can't go wrong with Peroni and the wine I chose was delicious. Ended up getting a bottle for the table. 

This meal and the ambiance transported me to Italy. Even though I have yet to go, this is what I imagine my meals would be like. 

Started off with an antipasto - premium meats and cheese and the big capers. To die for. Then we moved on to pizza and pasta. Splitting 2 of each between the 4 of us. Arugula truffle mushroom? And pepperoni. Can't recall exactly but regardless they were both delicious. One arriabata pasta and one baked. The baked rigatoni was the least favorite of all dishes by all but more like choosing your least favorite of something still amazing. 

Can't wait to go back. Sending my parents there. Would be great for a date night or 4-some. Not good for groups or small children. Parking is a downside but that is everywhere in north beach and the city. 

Caio!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Delicious food and vegetarian friendly!
Ordered pizza, lasagna, spicy pasta, dessert and wine and everything was amazing. If I had to choose a con: the bread was ok and cold. Great Tuscan Italian restaurant for birthdays and anniversaries.
author: Tulsi M.

description: Unremarkable but good pasta and pizza, but was extremely overpriced for small portion sizes.  Left hungry.
author: Katya R.

description:
Seriously thin, thin crust pizza. Wonder what their secret is?

My favorite is still the spicy calzone.

Can get packed at dinnertime, so call for a res if you can get through.

Parking in North Beach is always tough so factor that in if you decide to drive, or you might be super late.
author: Dennis W.

description: Wow! Amazing. If your looking for the true Italian restaurant experience then look no further!! Great food. Great service. Owners of this restaurant are from Italy. Would recommend to all friends and family! 2 thumbs up!!!
author: Tim K.

description: Quaint dining room, homemade pastas, great selection of wine, charming servers...It doesn't get much better than this. We'll be back!
author: Robin A.

description: This is the best thin crust pizza in San Francisco, hands down. The restaurant is a very cute and authentic Italian style place. It's small so you might have to wait, but everything is worth it. The caprese salad is outstanding as well.
author: Samara C.

description: The pizzas are amazing. We got 2 pizzas, 1) a shaved pear and blue cheese and 2) a pepperoni and sausage with garlic added. Both were mouth watering and incredible. It's served on very thin crust so it doesn't weigh you down like other pizza usually does. The family that owns it are also totally awesome. I can't wait to come back for the steak which the table across from us were RAVING about. Can't say enough good about the place. It's small so reservations are a good idea.
author: Jason P.

description: The pizza's were sooo good! Everyone at our table had a different kind and everyone was happy. I'm vegan, so I got a veggie one without cheese. Very flavorful.
author: Kate W.

description:
Dinner for 2, had to try this place due to the hype.

cotte de funghi 
- very thin crust fresh pizza made-to-order with mushrooms and a light prosciutto.  the crust was cooked to a perfect crisp without being burnt which was very impressive, however it was very bland.  I expected truffle oil or something grand considering the price, but unfortunately i've had better pizzas at half the price.

Eggplant Parmesan
- lots of flavors with cheeses, herbs, and pesto.  it was non-greasy however it was pretty thick.
- side salad was good with raw onions and a tart/salty dressing

Sorbetto Limone
- very tart and sweet and very "real".  the lemon tastes like you picked it straight out of a tree, unlike a frozen minutemaid

Chocolate Ice Cream Truffle (?)
- tasted like a cheap spumoni ice cream, unfortunately i'm not fond of the flavor.  the chocolate dust over the ice cream was awesome however.

Ambience was very upper class, family own-ed, little italy-esque, busy, yet romantic place.

Service was extremely friendly and very relaxed.  Lots of smiles and love.  However at this relaxed pace, the service was close to unbearably slow.  we were ready to order for about 10 minutes but the bus boy kept coming over and was not taking orders.  also after we finished the entrees, and our dishes were removed, it took 20 minutes before anyone offered us a dessert menu.  there was an excess amount of time between every step of the meal, which is fine, but it was borderline slow.  we were there for 1.5 hours and noticed that 4 other tables were in the same predicament.

overall this is a very legitamate italian restaurant, its good to at least try this place once, but i'd have to say it was just a-ok
author: Tina A.

description: Attentive and quick service outweighed by the excellent food. These folks are Italian. Best thin crust pizza ever. Made me wish I could eat three! Quality ingredients. We're going back. Wide variety of pizza that is not heavy in the least. You will want to try them all!
author: LInda S.

description:
A solid "meh - i've had better".  We went in with high hopes of a 4.5 star Italian spot.  Also with others saying they were blown away.. they seriously must have never eaten at an actually awesome Italian restaurant.

Things started off with the awkward question "Do you have a reservation?" and look as if we might not be seated.. when there are plenty of open tables.  The guy walked away from us (group of 3) without indication if we'd be seated.  It was ~8:30 on a Wednesday night.  He put us at a table next to their [tiny] bar.  My buddy asked us if we should leave.. but we were starving so we decided to roll the dice.

The burratta app ($14) was uninspired... no seasoning/fresh pepper/oil/balsamic.. nothing to elevate this dish besides the tiny bit of arugula.  The bruschetta ($11) was also underwhelming.  Decent flavor/bread, but again.. nothing that justified the price in my mind.  It was not a 4.5 star start by any means. I would have rather taken that $25 and bought a pizza somewhere else to feed us all.. and have $75 to get a bunch of good beers?  anyway.. too late, we're already there.

I ordered pesto pasta.  For the price it was solidly nothing special.  I make better pesto at home.  It was bland.. I had to load it with crushed red peppers for it to taste like something.  Their homemade egg noodles didn't seem to go well with the dish in my opinion.  My friend ordered lasagna which he said was "not tasty". My other friend said the calzone was OK - but he left most of it uneaten (this dish, unlike mine, was big).  We asked for bread with our dinner and it was never delivered.  I was looking forward to the bread since my pesto dish was pretty small, but didn't want to flag them down again and had finished our food before they came by our table.  

Anyway, the place in general was just nothing special.  The single bathroom was small and I had to wait for it to free up - no paper towels which is always a deduction to me (i hate those dyson air blades.. I always end up touching it).  The dining area is pretty loud and crowded - the server was standing in our way when we were trying to leave through the tight passageway of chairs.  Basically it was a dining experience where I felt like I would have rather grabbed a few random groceries and not gone out.
author: King B.

description: The food is certainly well worth the wait to be seated, however, be ready to deal with service that might be in line with what you would expect in a small village in Italy; painfully slow. Otherwise, if you're patient as a cucumber, the flavors are genuine, the quality is good, the portions are substantial and the wine list is in need of an overhaul.
author: Tibor K.

description: The pizza Monte Bianco was really good and it was very similar to authentic Pizza from Italy! I also tried the Baonecci salad which was a basic one with goat cheese and pear and that was good too. A little over priced but it was a nice experience
author: Brittany C.

description:
Small, welcoming, great service, amazing food. What else can I say? I love how unpretentious this restaurant is: the name of the food is in Italian, as you'd expect in any self-respecting North Beach restaurant, but the descriptions are simple and to the point. The starter platters won't fill you up before your mains, which is good news considering the servings are generous. The tiramisu was really good.

I guess some people save their 5 stars for really fancy restaurant. In this case I'm giving them 5 stars because I went for an intimate experience with delicious food and that's exactly what we got.
author: David G.

description: This is a small, informal, neighborhood place that serves high quality Italian food.  We showed up without reservations and got right in.  The server/host was warm and welcoming.  They have a diverse and well-priced Italian wine selection.  well cooked pastas - although they are listed as "primi," pastas are entree sized portions.  If you are intending to eat multiple courses, you should split the pasta among multiple guests.  Tagliatelli alla bolognese"  was awesome.  Cool, casual, friendly - genuine Italian. This place is definitely recommended.
author: James P.

description: Amazing Italian food and the people actually cooking your food are Italian. Fresh and authentic. Nice hole in the wall!
author: Anisha G.

description: Great Italian meal in North Beach. Bruschetta was an awesome appetizer. Lasagna was fantastic.
author: Vicki B.

description:
Came here based on the reviews with some co-workers

got a good table, but one of the girls with us has an allergy to gluten.  

We thought that there would be some dinner entrees with chicken, steak, pork, or fish that she could enjoy.

There was nothing, which was fine, but the owner's son was trying to talk over our server and tell us how that is not traditional Italian.  Which is funny because both myself and my friend are Italian and Italians defiantly use MEAT in their dishes.  That is fine if this is a vegetarian restaurant, but it's not.  So don't use that excuse that you don't want to purchase meats other than pizza toppings for your restaurant because you are cheap.

What was upsetting is that when we got up to leave because our friend couldn't eat here the owner's son scolded my other friend and said "next time look at the menu outside before you come in"  

Next time there won't be one here.  Because we will never be back.

We went next door to a place where they had Italian manners.
author: Carry B.

description:
We just had dinner here again! Twice in 10 days! This place is addicting. The food is incredible. The kitchen is like a Magic Shop.......
Stefania creates her magically tasty foods for all.
A must when in San Francisco.
This is the REAL DEAL!!!
author: Richard W.

description: I started off the night getting an unbelievable red wine. After looking at the menu I couldn't decide between a pizza or pasta. I decided to get both and bring half the pizza and half the lasagna I ordered home.  They brought out the pizza first and it was so delicious that I ate it all but one piece.  The crust was so light and the toppings and cheese amazing. Then they brought out the lasagna.  It was the best I've had. The cheese in it was creamy and the pasta was tender and light.   Needless to say I ate it all, including the last slice of pizza. Great place.  Exceptional service. Amazing food and wine.
author: Tim M.

description:
First off, you need to level your expectations for any 4.5 star restaurant....I'm sure the hype has contributed to the 1 and 2 star disappointed reviews.

Even though I don't usually like flatbread pizzas (e.g. cracker-like crusts), I thought the pizzas were delicious, and perhaps better than Delfina and Beretta due to better selection and quantity of toppings and overall flavor. Between 4 people we got 3 pizzas and bruschetta and were still a bit hungry, pizzas were expensive (~$19) but comparable in price and style to Deflina. I would recommend trying Baonecci at least once because they were good and unlike anything I've had in San Francisco.

If you pay a visit, get the Truffle Salame, which was hands down the table favorite, or the Porcini which was a close second. I'm a meat lover but felt the Salamino E Salccicia was a little boring, and would recommend something else. 

Not a big fan of the wine. Not a fan at all of the complimentary bread. Come for the pizza and go to Golden Boy if you're still hungry :)
author: Jess C.

description: Everything is delicious here!! Handmade, fresh. Everybody works here are the nicest and loving people. Give it a try
author: Tanya G.

description: I was here with family visiting my brother who had moved here about a year and a half ago and we wanted to go out and have one nice/dressier dinner so we chose here. It was such a great Italian restaurant. I have to say that I think this was the best meal I've ever eaten. I very rarely, and I mean rarely, ever finish my meal and I finished every last bit of this dish. Even though it was pasta, the dish was so light and was the perfect portion size. I got the Tagliatelle Aglio Olio e Peperoncino and it was fantastic!!! I will definitely have to come here every time I come to San Fran! They know how to do Italian food.
author: Marissa A.

description: Fantastic family-owned restaurant. You'll be either served or be waited on by one of the two sons, the dad is behind the bar and mom is in the kitchen. Very good, true Italian food. Wonderful atmosphere, great owners, good food all around. You may have to wait in line and the parking in the area is horrible, but it's hard to find parking in San Francisco no matter what.
author: Al G.

description:
Had my birthday dinner here in the private room in the back! Food was amazing. Highlight for me was the pesto pasta. I loved it! It is very light and fresh. Pizza, lasagna, meat and cheese plate, cannoli ... All perfect! We had the best service. Every need was taken care of. There were 12 of us and I would definitely recommend having a large group party here!  

I can't wait to go back for more pesto pasta!!
author: Kellie T.

description:
People are complaining about how thin the pizzas are but that just shows that those people don't know anything about authentic Italian pizza. I mean if you go there with expecting a regular Domino's Pizza, then yeah, you will be disappointed.

Both the pizza and the tiramisu were great.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
I thought it was hilarious that while people were lining up for hours to grab some mediocre Golden Boy Pizza, the stellar Caffe BaoNecci was pumping out the best pies in North Beach with little to no wait. Hipsters can be funny like that.

While there are other specialties on the menu like pastas and salads, it's the pizzas that steal the show. They're not like those limp creations Tony pumps out down the block either; the crust has such a satisfying crunch to it that doesn't come off as burnt. Toppings are stellar too, with combos like prosciutto and green olives working surprisingly well together.

It's just a shame it's not more popular...
author: Casey S.

description: Outstanding Italian fare. Reasonable prices. Lasagna amazing. Bolognese perfect. Would definitely come again.
author: William H.

description: Great Italian food, amazing thin crust pizzas, home made pasta, wonderful flavors! A bit pricey, but good service and authentic food. Loved it!
author: Shabina M.

description:
So glad that Tony's was backed up and we ambled our way here with our bellies ready to be satiated with food and drink.

SF gifted as a gorgeous blue sky and in gratitude we saluted with a bottle then two of the prosecco Classico. 

We had the four cheese calzone which was light and delightful with the marinara sauce on the side.

The salami and sausage pizza was unexpectedly excellent.  The crust is so thin and chewy with the right ratio of cheese and toppings to make for mouthfuls of sensory parties.

The pizza marguerite was light and a great option for vegetarians (speaking as an ex long term vegetarian).  Their pasta felt light to the digestion but heavy on the flavor.  Just right.
 
But we are so happy and thankful to our greedy appetites that we ordered another salami/sausage and asked the owner to recommend a pizza which he so very much delivered with a truffle, salami and arugula food orgasm evoking pizza.  This was the clear winner among winners of the night, this pizza made me seem, as the hostess, like a true in the know foodie who had planned this delectable experience beforehand as opposed to shamelessly leaning on my fellow yelp reviewers to feed our hungry out of town party.

Will most definitely keep this experience in my back pocket, ready to be whipped out for future guest impressing feasts!
author: Susana B.

description:
Not exactly what I was looking for.  The carpaccio was smoked and uneventful.  The meat tray well presented nicely was scimpy and not tasteful.  One piece of cheese. 
Walter the owner was nice.  His whole family ran the place but not a great  Italian experience.
author: Jane W.

description: Best Italian meat sauce I have ever had.  Great service, great family Chianti and port, and great cannelloni! Don't miss this place. You'll regret it if you do.
author: Bruce O.

description:
What a hidden gem! We were getting personalized fortune cookies done at Golden Gate fortune cookie company and wanted to get lunch nearby. Relied on Yelp to find this lovely gem. 

We split a pizza (waiter's favorite) and a salad (Stefania). The pizza was outstanding! So light and airy, the flavors perfectly complemented. Oh my, it was love in a bite! I love that it's family owned and it was funny that you have to walk through the kitchen (very clean by the way) to use the bathroom!

The only reason for the 4 star over the 5 star is the pizzas really are made for one person, too small to share. The couple next to us were eating an additional slice of pizza from Golden Boy next door after eating lunch here! Too funny.

My advice, order one pizza per person.....We will definitely come back to try some of the other ones!
author: Betty C.

description: To be honest, this was highly disappointing. We ordered a bottle of wine, a pizza and pasta.  The pizza was bland and tasteless for $19 I expected better. Pasta was good but super small for $18. The bottle of wine for $38 which was decent. Definitely not the caliber we were expecting or paid for. Maybe for $40, not $90......
author: Rachel C.

description:
I'm giving the restaurant 3 stars primarily because of the competition in the area.  It is good food and you can't really go wrong.  I had the Lasagna and my wife had one of their thin Pizzas.  She loved it and considered it to be one of the best she's had.  She loves thin-crust pizza.  I didn't taste it, but it looked good.  My Lasagna was good, but it was one of those "white" type of lasagnas that didn't have a lot of tomato sauce flavoring.  It was good, but it is not my type.  It is worth considering if that is the style of Italian that they prepare there in their other dishes and it is what you like.

We went on a very slow night.  We were one of two tables occupied at dinner.  I found the waiter to be very nice, but overall the service was a bit "blah".  We didn't get bread until the food arrived and if I recall, we asked for it.  The waiter and two others pretty much just stood around not doing much.   Our overall experience was OK, but very simple and non-special.  If you're looking for a nice evening with great food, great ambience, and outstanding service this may not be your place.  If you don't mind just going in, sitting down, eating your food and leaving ... then you can't go wrong.  It is good food and your belly will be happy.  Mine was!
author: Leo Q.

description: A date introduced me to this restaurant last year, and now whenever I want exquisite Italian food this is where I go. I've tried a handful of Italian restaurants, as a major pasta fanatic... This is by far the most authentic, fresh pasta with the lightest, simplest, and most natural ingredients. I come out of here feeling satiated and light, unlike the other Italian restaurants in the neighborhood that make me feel like I just consumed a dish drenched in hydrogenated fat.  The atmosphere is simple and elegant yet homey and colorful at the same time. Very warm and welcoming. Of course it's not inexpensive, but it is definitely worth it.
author: C. C.

description:
In a neighborhood filled with pizza and Italian restaurants, Baonecci is a gem. While it is off the main drag and has an unassuming storefront, don't let appearances deceive you. Instead, follow your nose; the lovely aromas of fresh garlic, salty mozzarella, and fruity wines draw you in like an open hand extended. 

My boyfriend and I were greeted at the door promptly, and were seated shortly thereafter, which was much appreciated as it was late Friday night and we were starving! The interior was oddly decorated with large photographs and graphic prints, but the overall impression was pleasing. There was a certain authenticity to the atmosphere, with its low lighting and feeling of fullness thanks to lively conversation and laughter filling the air. My boyfriend said it reminded him of the trattorias that he often visited while living in Rome. There was a small tea light lit on each table, lending a flickering glow. It felt quite intimate.

The server was warm and charming, and we felt at ease as we took some time considering our options. We selected a glass of Sangiovese (acidic and bright) and a glass of Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, (soft and fruity), along with a quarto fromagi pizza. We decided to start small since we wanted to save room for the house-made desserts. 

Since moving to San Francisco, Benjamin and I have had trouble locating a place that serves thin crust pizza in the Roman style. Boanecci served us just that. The quarto fromagi was to die for! The crust was wood fired, with lovely bits of charring around the edges, and the cheese was melty and flavorful. There was a perfect swirl of rich olive oil as a base and a good amount of herbs to round out the dish. I even loved that there was a light dusting of corn meal on the crust, a testament to hand stretching and firing. My only suggestion to the cook is that they add more fresh basil to top the pizza. 

We loved the pizza so much that we ordered a second, a traditional Margherita. I wasn't as pleased with this one. The mozzarella and basil were solid, but the tomato flavor of the sauce was less pronounced than I would have liked. However, we still ate it up, as the crust was so delicious. 

Throughout the meal, the servers and the restaurant manager checked in on us, making sure that we were taken care of without being intrusive. I felt like a family friend dining in their home. 

The dessert of the day was tiramisu, so, even though we were quite full at this point, we couldn't resist. It was served in a glass dish, and had a more pudding-like quality to it, which is more traditional. The ladyfingers still had a spongy spring, and were drenched in a bittersweet and tart espresso that complimented the creamy, buttery mascarpone. A sprinkle of cocoa on top added a hint of dryness and created a beautiful mouth feel in combination with the other textures in the dish. 

I'm so happy to have found a great Italian restaurant in the city and can't wait to return to try other dishes.
author: Mars W.

description:
When you die, if you've been *very, very good*, then you get to spend eternity eating at Baonecci.

I had the tagliatelle arrabiata, and did I openly weep with joy?  I did not.  I am a MAN, and I don't do those things.  At least not in public.  Later, in the privacy of my room, I may have leaked a little.  Don't judge me.

My wife had a personal pizza which came on a cracker-thin (and crisp) crust.  I tried some, and really had the only problem I've ever had with Baonecci: the angels that sang as I bit into it were annoyingly loud.  The restaurant should look into toning them down a bit.
author: Matt M.

description: Awesome food! The pizza is incredible! Thin, cracker like, crust with fresh ingredients. The service is wonderful as well. Loved this place
author: Christy P.

description:
My friends and I have this thing where every time Mike L. can't join us for dinner, we all take photos of our food and send it to him.  So basically on the night we went to BaoNecci (and to Naia afterwards), he received a complete view of the pizza from all 4 angles.

Poor Mike.

But not us, because a few friends and I were able to enjoy delicious pizza at their super cute, cozy restaurant a few skips away from Tony's.  Unfortunately the food wasn't memorable enough for me to even remember what we ordered, though I do believe the Margherita pizza was on our table, since it's a staple for me.  Everything we had was fresh and delicious, so I'd definitely give it another shot.

Good alternative to Tony's, especially if you can snag a reservation on OpenTable.
author: Tori S.

description: Best Italian dinner I've had outside Italy. We started with the Prosciutto e Melon ... Perfect combination of sweet and salty. We followed this by the Baonecci Salad ... Cool crisp lettuce with pears and goat cheese with just enough dressing to add flavor but not drown the salad. Our entree was the Tagliatelle al Ragu Di Carne ... How do you miss with homemade pasta and a delicious sauce. Some homemade deserts with a cappuccino ... Bread made on site ... Pure heaven. If I lived in San Francisco, this would be a regular spot for me. Good service without any hovering ... Led to a leisurely meal ... Felt more like dinner at mama's than dinner at a restaurant.
author: Bob G.

description: Best home cooking in North Beach. It's the real thing, like being in Italy. Which may be why some Ignoramuses here on yelp give it less than five stars. They have never had the real thing, only the pumped up steroids USA versions of Italian fancy restaurants. This is simply basic amazing pasta and pizza. Great service. Great lady chef. Make a reservation.
author: Girlie G.

description: We loved everything about this place... almost. The eggplant parmigiana was amazing as well as the tagliatelle and the pizza. Warning: the fagioli is not vegetarian. We were so disappointed when we brought it home.
author: Cherkea H.

description: I really like this place! Small, quaint, warm and cozy. It feels "family owned". The chef even came out to ask if we were happy with our meal. The menus offers traditional Italian cuisine accompanied by an awesome selection of Italian wines. Good for dinner with girls or date night.
author: Roxanne D.

description:
Tasty but pricey.
Each pizza is made to feed just 1 person, but prices range from $15-$20. 
Is it better than Pizza Hut & Dominoes? YES!!! But its still expensive for pizza for its size!!

I got the Contadina ($16.95) which had thin spiral-y pear slices on top of a deliciously cheesy crispy thin crust pizza. The pears added a freshing taste and the cheese & pears went surprisingly well together. I highly recommend this pizza!

My friend got the Maremma Diavola which has spicy tomato sauce & parsley toppings. The sauce was definitely home made and this was really good, except for the fact that it is SPICY! (or I'm just a wimp!)

The decor is cute with strings of lights and pictures decorating the place. Its family run and small, but is a cute place to go with your family, friends or siggy other. You can take a stroll along North Beach after with the transamerica building as your backdrop. 

Overall, I really liked the fresh ingredients and well hand crafted pizzas, but the price tag will likely keep me from coming back and stuffing my face for a while.
author: Emily C.

description: Was dying for eggplant parm made the Tuscany way.  It was the perfect size and came with a side salad on the plate. It was fantastic.  The people that worked there were all Italian and very pleasant.  So glad we walked through North Beach.
author: Suedeo D.

description:
If you can't decide on what to order, get the Monte Bianco and Truffle Salame pizzas!! You will not be disappointed.

My friend and I came to North Beach craving clam pizza, but we knew we came on the wrong day when we turned the street corner and saw the ridiculous throng of drunk people from St. Patty's Day bar crawls. The wait at Tony's was 2 hours and the line for Golden Boy was out the door, so we decided to call BaoNecci's to see how long their wait was. They surprisingly said they had a table available for us and we noticed this was because they had a "Reservations Only" sign on their door that day, to keep out the drunks I'm assuming. I thought that was kind of funny. 

I'm not usually a thin crust pizza fan, but their Monte Bianco and Truffle Salame are amazing! I wasn't even sad about not being able to eat clam pizza anymore. We decided to do half and half with these two because they both sounded really good and we thought 2 whole pizzas would have been too much. The main toppings on the Monte Bianco were prosciutto and marscapone cheese and I thought the saltiness and slight sweetness complimented each other well. The Truffle Salame had salami and truffle topped with arugula. Truffle and arugula are two of my favorite things to eat ever so I thought this one was amazing too! The crust was a little too thin for me, but that's just my preference because I usually like doughy crusts. Oh and we also shared the Stefania salad (romaine lettuce, walnuts, apple slices, and Swiss cheese cubes), which was way better than I expected. The dressing was light and all the ingredients were really fresh. It's a little pricey- we paid about $20 each for the pizza and salad and I was still a little hungry...but that pizza was amazing so I'll definitely be back!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I visited Cafe BoaNecci when I was in town for a conference.  I had a list of places I wanted to try out, but stumbled on this place when walking through Little Italy.  After my first visit, I crossed off the other pizza places on my list and came back for more.

I was lucky enough to spend some time in Italy with a friend many years ago.  This is hands down the best pizza I have had since that visit.   I got Speck and Mushroom on my first visit and Pancetta and mushroom on my second visit.  (I really like cured meat and fungus pizzas).

Heaven.  It is pizza heaven.  The crust is thin and crispy, the cured meat is quality, he cheese is perfect and the wine i amazing.
