description:
Inattentive servers and mediocre pizzas. I've been to Italy and I'm still searching for similar tasting pies in SF. 

I was hoping this would be the one, based on the ratings and proximity (North Beach). So very disappointing.
author: Nansee P.

description: The food was delicious.  The pizza is cracker thin; covered with delicious toppings.  Only reason this place doesn't rate 5 stars: they don't give you enough food for the price.  What you do get is amazing, top quality.  Just don't come here with a big appetite and expect to leave full.  I would still recommend this place with the one caveat.
author: Spiro C.

description: Incredibly good pasta. Some of the best pasta with pesto I have ever had. Pizza is very good as well. Very good friendly service
author: Christian D.

description:
Walked past BaoNecci around 5pm one Tuesday afternoon.  I was the first customer that evening, so I got their full attention.  The Italian waiters are very friendly, casual yet attentive.  The place itself is simple but warm; it really reminded me of many similar neighborhood pizzerias in Italy. 

Now, about that pizza: I like simple pizza toppings, so I asked for the prosciuto and funghi.  The pizza topping was very correct, even it it lacked a bit more tomato sauce for my taste.  However, the thin crust has two shortcomings.  First of all, it was strangely tasteless (lacking more salt or time, or whatever) .  Also, it was just a bit overdone, it even splintered when cut.  First, I thought it was just mine, but then another table got their pizzas, and I could hear the crunching noises all the way across the restaurant!   I guess it's a question of taste, but I like mine just a bit softer.  

In any case, don't let me put you off.  It's a simple place with good vibes and decent pizza.  By all means, go.
author: Pascal M.

description:
It was a crowded Friday night and my group (well, actually just me really) wanted Italian to make our touristy North Beach experience complete. None of the restaurants seemed to take reservations though, so when we managed to get a table for 5 at Caffe BaoNecci I was a little worried that Yelpers had made a mistake. How could such a highly-rated restaurant come at no cost? Thankfully I worried for nothing.

Everybody's going to talk about the food first but hey, at Caffe BaoNecci, you don't just get a treat for the tummy but for the eyes as well. Two servers were extremely easy on the eye, and came equipped with the biggest, cutest smiles (teehee). But onto the serious stuff: BaoNecci's thin-crust pizzas are SERIOUSLY good. No joke about it. We had the Truffle Salame pizza and as soon as it came out of the kitchen, the fragrance just hits you in the face without being overwhelming (can you actually BE overwhelmed by truffle oil)? Each crunchy, crispy bite was a trip to Textured, Tasty Heaven. We had a little awkward situation when one slice lingered on the plate, and everyone was clearly hankering over it, but that just goes to show how delish it was. We also had a Capricciosa pizza (tomatoes, proscuitto), creamy burrata, and proscuitto parma ham, which were all good, but I think the truffle salame is definitely the star of the show. 

Oh wait, but how could I forget the Nutella + fruits pizza? Yes, their profit margin for this dessert dish must be ridiculously high but UGH THIS IS SIN THAT YOU CAN EAT. Chocolately hazelnut goodness with an abundance of strawberries and kiwis and bananas on a crispy thin-crust bed topped with sugar? HOW CAN YOU GO WRONG? I mean, I suppose if I came here everyday, I'd be 200 pounds overweight and wondering how I let myself go this far... But for now, man. Nutella pizza, I dreamt of you last night. (Please share this dish though, it can be a little... too much for just one person :p)
author: Rachel A.

description: The absolute best and most unique item at BaoNecci  is the Prosciutto Salad Sandwich! This is something you cannot get anywhere else. Plus, I love the family! Been going here since they took over the old cookie store.
author: Rudy T.

description:
Pizza. The best pizza ever, hands down. Or, if you prefer,

"Hands up pardner, we all are rustling away your pizza, because we can!"

I love the thin crust any day, but the Caffe BaoNecci makes the thin crust crispy, which with the wet sauce on top is quite a feat. I likes me the crunch with my pizza. 

I will be back for the bread (focaccia looks divine) and pastries another time.
author: Zuki J.

description:
Love this place. Small so hard to get a table right away.
Also reasonable corkage fee if you want to bring your own wine.
Pizzas are great - napoletana !! But not soggy/wet sloppy stuff.
Staff is all italian I believe and quite helpful.

Will go back to try some pasta next time.
author: Neil B.

description: Good restaurant in North Beach.  I had the burrata salad which was terrific and the eggplant parm which was good.  I need to go back again to try other plates but I liked it and the service was very good.  Most others in the restaurant were eating pizza that looked very good and smelled great.
author: Mark B.

description:
This was a poor outcome for us, none of us in our party got the pizza, so that might have what turned my rating down. No why is it: Did we not dress nice enough -  the waiter was plain rude, did he not like us being German and expected little tip by German tourists anyway? My pesto noodles were like noodles and pesto from Trader Joes, nothing special to them only the high price tag to it. I liked the place being busy and close together, also the good wine selection, but the food could not surprise. Hard for me to head back to try out their pizza. Yes their appetizer bread was good. But that could not turn me around.
We finished and I tipped the German way - zero.
author: Wolfgang I.

description:
After trying to go to Tony's and being told that the wait was over two hours...our party of 7 got seated immediately at BaoNecci and were treated to one of our best SF meals. The pizza was ridiculously good, the crust is cracker thin and perfectly prepared. My highlights were the Parma and Contadina pizzas. The service was fantastic as well, you can tell they take a lot of pride in their restaurant and their food.

I'm sold!
author: Pascal F.

description:
After going on a really awful tour of chinatown. My friend and I needed a change of scenery and quick. 

So I yelped best pizza in san fran and this place came up. So we made our way to this cute little restaurant. 

My friend and I had strawberry bellinis. The antipasto dish and pizza. The drink was so fresh I could have had more than just one. The antipasto dish had a variety of meats and cheeses and the best olives I have ever had. The pizza was awesome.  The servers were friendly and cute too. Hehe. 

A definite must try!
author: Jenna S.

description: Before my recent trip to San Francisco, I scoured Yelp reviews for great pizza places in the North Beach area. This restaurant got the overall best reviews, so I wanted to try it out. I was most definitely NOT disappointed. I ordered a carafe of red wine at a very reasonable price. They have a huge selection of vegetarian pizzas on their menu, and I chose the Bufalina. It was the thinnest crust pizza I have ever had, and it was AMAZING! My overall experience was phenomenal; everything was perfect. The reviews do not lie--this is the best authentic Italian pizza place in North Beach.
author: Leah A.

description:
My family and I firmly believe that this was the best meal of our week-long stay in San Francisco. The location is a bit out of the way, but well worth the walk!  The service was very friendly.

My mom and I split a pizza with four cheese and pear slices, and it was fantastic! The pizzas my dad and brother ordered were just as good. What we can't seem to get out of our minds, though, are the desserts. We ordered and devoured four of them along with some delicious cappuccinos. My dad, who is not usually a big dessert-eater, loved their limoncello and lemon sorbetto dessert, declaring it his new favorite dessert ever. And that's really saying something.
author: Elyse P.

description:
best place i've had pizza in SF so far, and i've lived here for two years now, and i love me some pizza.
the bufalina pizza is especially awesome, as is the truffle pizza (but i hate arugula, so we get it with basil instead YAY!)

and it's a little, authentic, family-run place, which brings me right back to italy and makes me feel all warm and fuzzy inside :)
author: Molly E.

description: Great thin/crispy crust pizza selection, great service & a cool vibe are all things that will definitely prompt me to return.
author: Miguel S.

description:
Caffe' Baonecci serves AUTHENTIC Italian pizza! If you prefer an American style pizza, full on condiments, then you won't like this place. Their pizza has a very thin crust with minimal ingredients, just the way we enjoy it back home :)
It's run by a lovely family and their service is always very friendly. The only reason why I didn't give it a full 5 stars review is the fact that I find their prices a little too high. Other than that, I love Caffe' Baonecci!
author: Silvia I.

description:
I haven't had pizza like this since I was in Italy,  And after studying abroad there and eating pizza most every day, that says a lot!

What makes it so authentic is the  tomato sauce, which is sweet, thin and delicious.  This is the best Italian-style pizza I've had in the states.

We ordered the margherita and it took a while for the pizza to come out but it was so worth it.  They charged a butt-load for the mozzarella bufala substitute but that also, was so worth it.

Come, eat and be Italian for a night!
author: Becca S.

description: Just like in Roma, super thin cracker style crust. Not greasy like I usually see in SF. Is not your five style Delfina but this is probably closer to the real deal of an authentic Pizzeria Italiana.
author: marco B.

description:
You know when you're new to a neighborhood, and then you get really sick of the restaurants around you? Not this place. I seriously get food here once a week, and I've been working next to them for a year now.

There are only a couple of places I've been to that can keep my attention for that long. The food is delicious. Pizza, salads, and their tuna sandwich is the best I've had! Service is excellent, and the atmosphere is great. 

Love these guys!
author: Mez L.

description: When you go, you feel transported to another place. If you've been to Italy, you feel as if you're back at your favorite local pizzeria, having the house wine without question, and enjoying meals that can take hours but go by in an instant. A gem and a favorite, among many, in North Beach.
author: Marc M.

description: I literally cannot imagine a better pizza than the Monte Bianco. I'm not saying it's impossible (though unlikely) but that I can't think of anything that would improve this masterpiece. When the savory, light prosciutto and the creamy melting mascarpone cheese on top of the thin crust and fresh sauce and mozzarella all come together in unison for that first bite it's hard not to tear up a little bit. I would gladly recommend this place to anyone looking for an amazing meal, I can't wait to come back myself.
author: Derek D.

description: Best thin crust I've eaten in SF so far.  The ingredients in the pizza are amazing.  The only disappointment is the price.  The pizza is definitely not cheap.  You will definitely need to eat five of these at $20 a pop to get full.  Walk in's are tough so its recommended to make a reservation cuz they will turn yo fatty ass away.  I highly recommend trying to thin crust if you have already eaten at Tony's Pizza.
author: Fatty A.

description: I went with my husband. I had the burrata salad (fresh mozzarella, tomatoes and arugula) and the capressa pizza.  My husband the bean soup and pesto pasta. We also had the family house wine.  All were outstanding. Only minor complaint is there were no meat dishes. We were hoping for wild boar pasta or other meats typically found in Italian Restaurants but none were offered. It might be vegetarian? Wait staff are terrific.  We greatly
author: renee m.

description: Little spot, you could almost miss it. We were lucky to be the next couple to get a table on a Tuesday night at 7:30, I bet it's reservations only on weekends. Busy and small, but not noisy and they manage to turn tables easily. I never saw anyone turned away or wait more than a few minutes. A place for parties 4 or less, a few tables for up to 5/6. We ordered the bolognese  and margherita pizza, and two Chiantis. The wine was ok, though you can order higher prices bottles well up into the multi-hundred dollar range if you wish. The pizza was amazingly paper thin and still was able to hold itself together. Like eating the crisped edges of philo dough, which I love. Though I could've used some red pepper to make the flavor pop. The bolognese was the star of the meal, and it looked like most people were ordering pasta. The bolognese had a meaty flavor beyond the ground meat you would buy and season, certainly something the home cook should try to replicate. Perfect ratio between meat, sauce and fresh pasta.
author: C M.

description:
Well unfortunately I am not writing about the food, but the lack of courtesy and rudeness of the employees.  It was about 8:30 p.m. Monday night on 8/8/2011 and my wife and I along with our little baby girl thought it would be a great idea to stop by North Beach in our old haunts and grab a bite to eat before we drive back to the East Bay.   I have heard and wanted to try the pizza here at BaoNecci, so we pay for parking across the street, $11.00 and walk across the street.  

Before going inside I noticed that there were3 tables empty outside and inside about 2 tables left and the rest are filled with patrons eating their tasty looking pizzas.  Also we wanted to go somewhere cozy where it was nice and warm because it was a bit chilly outside.  So my wife goes inside and says can we get a table for 4, because we are waiting for a couple of friends who were about 10 minutes away.  The waiter or host goes to the back by the register talks to whoever that was behind it comes back and says ok and then proceeds to ask, is the other party here yet? Obviously no, but told them they should be here shortly.  Well he said, since we don't do reservations, we will seat you once they get here. 

 WHOAAAAAAAAAA..PUT ON THE BRAKES!! I looked around the restaurant, sure didn't look like the French Laundry, nor Boulevards,  nor any 4 or 5 star restaurants that I have been to here in the states or overseas.   It is 8:30 p.m., its cold outside., the restaurant is not full, no one was waiting and sure didn't see a crowd trying to make their way in.  Plus we have a baby in our arms.  The right thing to say was, oh since they are on the way have a seat, let me tell you about the wines or beers that we serve (hint hint $$$$) you shouldn't go back outside in the cold with your baby, AND YES WE WOULD LIKE YOUR BUSINESS AT 8:30 P.M..

So who am I? Well I am not a food critic or a food snob, but I am a patron to the city of San Francisco and its hole in the walls to fine establishments.  But I do have 28 years of restaurant experience and grew up in one, since my mother and father owns one of the oldest restaurants in Sonoma County.  I spend very good money and have a very large circle of friends that we like to recommend eating establishments to and basically have had it all.  

We have never been so rudely treated and walked away with a bitter taste in our mouths.  I am sure I will end up trying this pizza place, but really in no hurry anymore, if they are still around.  So to the owners or restaurant employees, please learn some etiquette when it comes to dealing with customer's and please don't give me "OH everyone needs to be here to be seated".  You are not that type of restaurant to warrant that type of attitude or behavior.
author: victor s.

description: Six of us celebrated  a birthday here on a Saturday night. Not sure I would go back. Cannelloni was good but eggplant was dry and tasteless. Had 2 appetizers that were good but small and overpriced. The service and staff was good but overall the food was mediocre.
author: Merrie D.

description:
Never know a delicious pizza can be that simple!  

Light and flavorful tomato sauces and super fresh ingredients on a very thin crust pizza!  OMG...it was so good!  

We also tried Caprese (Tomato with Mozzarella).  Everything was so fresh.  I especially like they added olive oil on the Mozzarella cheese.  It made the cheese flavors more standout!  

The service was excellent there!  Very warm, friendly and attentive.  

The restaurant is kinda small.  If you go there during the peak hours, prepare to wait but definitely worth it!
author: Liza T.

description:
So I've been here a few times now and I decided to bring my whole family and enjoy some Italian pizza. The Gambaccinis treated us like family, played with the kids, and left everyone saying wow that was good homemade Italian pizza. The crust was handmade and crispy, sauce was simple and flavorful, and according to Papa Gambaccini, Good Luck finding this prosciutto in San Francisco because they special order it by the huge slab from southern Italy and slice it thin for us to enjoy. Anyone and everyone that misses Italy you must come and support this great gem.

Recommendations:
- BaoNecci Monte Bianco Pizza.
- Chocolate Tartufo for dessert.
author: R J.

description:
This made me realize how much I love thin crust pizza in a total family environment.  It was a great experience to come into a family owned place where they have so much passion for the food and the customers.

I went with friends who are regulars so we got great service.  We ate late so by the time we were done, the family was sitting down for their dinner.

They surprised us with an amazing, homemade dessert pizza with fresh fruit and nutella.  Amazing.  Looking forward to coming back soon!
author: Ayelet B.

description:
The pizza here is authentic Italian thin crust. I ordered the margerhita and was very impressed by the quality of the pizza. The sauce was perfect and there was a good balance between cheese and sauce. The crust is paper thin and perfectly cooked. 

Service is very good as well. Hard to do much better than this if you are looking for a quick bite in North Beach.
author: G K.

description: We ordered two half pizzas (something with porsciutto and something with arugula on it), porsciutto melon, and the baonecci salad. Everything was fine, but not exquisite. The price I thought was more exquisite than the food. Given the plethora of Italian eateries nearby, it is unlikely I will want to return here.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Really, really good thin crust pizza. The crust totally stands out... it's cracker thin, yet soft and doesn't get mushy.  

The ingredients are all fresh and tasty.  Really enjoyed the pizza's here...although we had to order 3 to get full for the whole family since they the crust was think.
author: Vien C.

description: Red and white checkered tablecloths, really solid thin-crust pizza, family-owned italian joint. Everything's comforting. If I were in the neighborhood this would be my default pizza joint.
author: Ben M.

description: After reading all the reviews I thought Baonecci was going to be the best of the best. Not so much. Nothing wowed us (party of 8 at two tables because they claimed they did not take reservations for more than 6, and yet there was a table of 8 seated in the resteraunt when we arrived.) The salads were boring and expensive for what was on the plate. Pizzas were thin as expected, but uninspired, not expected. Lasagna was meh. Best thing- noodles with butter for the 7 year old.
author: KJ A.

description: Cute pizza joint with great thin crust (think cracker-like) pizza.  We had the bresaola appetizer and then the truffle salami pizza.  A bit overpriced ($18.95) given how small/thin it was, but oh well.  I would prefer the pizza at Tony's, but this place takes reservations.  Cute atmosphere.  Cozy and warm.
author: B. Y.

description:
I like the place because ....

1. Not modern 
2. Not a new
3. Not a high-end decor
4. Not pricy
5. Not a California "Fusion" cuisine
6. Basic Italian cafe food
7. local small mom & pop cafe
8. Love the fresh made cappuccino, even though the regular coffee on the hot-plate was extremely terrible! 
9. GOOD SERVICE! People here were really nice, made us very comfortable
10. Cozy

That is why I like North Beach.
Basically San Francisco gets so many tourists everywhere but I don't get tired and feel uncomfortable with them because I can become an instant tourist in a second, any time I want.
I still can enjoy the feeling like visiting foreign place, like here, authentic and reasonable.

That's right, I am like a chameleon.
I am a residence in the city also I can be a tourist.
author: Nobu K.

description: We stumbled across this place without knowing the review, just looked for a place for a quick bite before a concert and turned out it's a pleasant surprise :) I recently moved to the west coast and one of the things I missed is the new york pizza. And BaoNecci do have pretty good pizza! We ordered Bruschetta and Monte Bianco shared btw 2 people. The crust was thin and crispy and the ingredients were fresh and tasty. The serving staffs are pretty friendly. I can see this place can be nice for a date and it's small and cozy. I'd like to go check out other items on the menu when I have the chance.
author: Eunice S.

description:
Let me get straight to the point and say that this place has THE best pizza in Cali. I ordered their eggplant parmigiana, and my bf ordered a thin crust pizza which was perfectly topped with proscuitto, cheese and had just a good enough amount of tomato sauce. I apologize for not remembering what type of cheese it was, but what i do remember is the THIN and ohsodelicious crispy crust!

Of all the spots I have reviewed so far, this is NUMBER UNO on my list for anyone in the bay area to hit up! you def have to come here and try their pizza!
author: Christina D.

description: Sorry the pizza was just not for me and I love thin crust.  It's a very cute place though.
author: hannah t.

description:
There are not enough words to describe how wonderfully friendly and lovely the Gambaccini famliy who own Caffé Bao Necci are, and how amazing Stefania's cooking is. The food is authentic, flavorful, and light. Don't expect heavy Italian American food and huge portions, the food here is served in normal portions. You will be pleasantly surprised to discover beautiful Tuscan style Italian food :)  
_I recommend the Contadina 
(white cheese pizza, super think cracker like crust, with shaved spirals of fresh pair).
_The Stefania salad :)
_The cookies are all amazing, but the biscotto is out of this world :)
_Thursday nights they have a fixed menu dinner featuring a variety of their amazing pizzas, and starters, and they play subtitles Italian films. It is the sweetest thing ever, I would recommend going with friends or on a date. RSVP for this is a must, and well worth it :)
author: maria a.

description:
Hands down the best pizza in SF!! Besides, the service couldn't get any better, family owned and family operated. 

The wine list is also really good but what is really good is the pasta, try the arrabiata... and I almost forget: fagioli a'l ucceletto (or whatever the right spelling is) don't ask, just order it, you'll thank me later. 

Keep it up guys!!
author: Tina B.

description: Came here on the first night of our long weekend in SF. Service was good & attentive. We shared 2 pizzas, a salad & dessert between 2 people and left stuffed to the rafters. We had the caprese salad. It was ok - tomatoes weren't the best or quite ripe. We had the mushroom & pancetta pizza which was quite good. The other pizza we had was the Italian sausage...nothing to brag about, quite bland really. For dessert, we had the chocolate tartufo. It was pretty good, but again rather plain. Can't say I'd go back.
author: Katie E.

description:
We wanted to go somewhere unique, to celebrate our friend the Beautiful Man's domination of the weekend's festivities.  The atmosphere was down to earth, with classic checkered table clothes, authentic decorations and staff.  Our appetizer was wonderful, with fantastic bread, cheeses, jam and melon.  Andy was willing to share his main course with others,and Xena, after insisting on a group dining experience, enjoyed two helpings of Andy's classically attired thin-crust pizza -- a treat for all.  
It was the perfect complement to the Chairman's Suite, where we had stayed for the weekend. One of our group had came out of the gates fast early on, with his eyes writing bigger checks than he could cash, but the Calzone and wine turned him into a puddled mess.  Solid work.
author: Kc K.

description:
Service is okay at best. They wouldn't let my party of two sit at a 4 person table, even though it was 2pm and business was slow. Later a 2 person party came and they let them sit there.

It is a tiny place, with tiny tables and a very quaint atmosphere. The funny part is that at lunch, most people dining there are two men. Many of them are Italian, so I guess that is an indication of the authenticity of the food.

The food was pretty good. The paninis are a very good lunch deal for around 7 to 8 dollars. The paninis are a good size and come with a side salad. The pizzas are cracker-thin, very authentic Italian pizzas. I wish I had chosen the margherita because the ham and mushroom one I got was good, but I wanted some delicious mozzarella on top.
author: Cathy S.

description: Good thin classic style pizza crust. Friendly and helpful service, too.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
So authentic I swear the staff and customers were speaking more Italian than English, which is a nice touch for this charming spot. I had been a few weeks back for lunch (enjoyable slice of focaccia with tomato sauce), and this morning I was celebrating the still good vibes from the previous night's Kaskade/Ronski Speed epic. Liked my egg whites in tomato sauce, though on the heavier side and priced a bit high ($10). If you dig polenta over fruit in the morning, you might be a little more generous with the stars.

Read nothing but good things about the family running this place, do hope they make it.
author: Jason B.

description:
The best pizza vie ever had! Monte blanco:  SM tomato sauce, prosciutto, mozzarella, a dollop of mascarpone cheese in the middle of the pie. The thinnest, most airy crust I've ever had. 

Only one complaint: I had to share it with my BF. I think I'll have to lose him next time so I can eat the whole thing like the piggy I am!
author: Erika A.

description: The place was very empty and setting looked somewhat like an ice cream parlor rather than an Italian restaurant. They had a good caesar salad though! I'm very pick about my caesar dressings, and I definitely liked this one. The pizza was pretty good-- thin crust, so it's not overly filling like most pizza. I liked the italian sausage one best. Friendly staff too.
author: Megan F.

description: closest food to Italy I have found in the Bay Area! Can't get enough of this place! Try the spicy arrabbiata pasta and the truffle salami pizza. Top it off with the tiramisu.
author: Payal A.

description: Pear and gorgenzola pizza is awesome, seemed like a small family run place...great place to take a date...quiet place, considering it's in north beach.  Great food and atmosphere.
author: Andrea D.

description:
This is fabulous, thin-crust, authentic Italian pizza! BaoNecci is family-owned spot and they obviously take pride and enjoyment in their cooking. The ingredients are simple, fresh, and high-quality. They certainly do the right thing in using the best stuff, in moderated quantities - just the right ratio of sauce:dough:cheese:topping.

The pizza sauce has wonderful flavor and they import it from Italy (you can also pick it up from Molinari's, round the corner). It is not overly sweet and has a great tang. I had the margherita, but stuck with the standard mozzarella, which was great. Next time I would ask for more basil, as it only had two small, whole leaves. Crisp, crunchy crust and no soggy middle :)

The place was cozy and bustling - they were super accommodating when we asked to sit outside on a chilly December evening, even though they had to make up a table for us.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
I first read about Caffe BaoNecci in the SF Examiner where Patricia Unterman raved about it.  She called it one of the most authentic and endearing restaurants in the North Beach Area.  We tried it on early evening and find Patricia's rating highly overrated.

We ordered the BaoNecci Monte Bianco pizza for $15.95 which was rated well.  The crust was thin and was like a huge water cracker.  There were slivers of tomatoes covered by thin slices of proscuitto and a dollop of mascarpone cheese.  It was plain tasting and not very filling.

Additionally we ordered a lasagne dish with meat sauce on top with some parmigiano cheese for $12.95. It was served on a dish similar to what they served banana splits on.  It was also very blah.

I don't disparage people for eating here for its "authenticity", but it is not for us.  A COSTCO pizza and a frozen Stouffer's lasagna has better flavor than Caffe BaoNecci.
author: Robert J.

description: Not gonna lie, we were a little turned off when we walked in and realized how tiny this place was...but we stuck with it based on previous reviews and whoa...so happy we did. Delicious, fresh, and (from my non-Italian heritage) authentic Italian food. So good, reasonably priced. Only draw back is having to walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom...gotta be a health hazard but good this good I don't care.
author: Rachel W.

description:
One of my favorite spots in SF for a nice Saturday or Sunday lunch.
Yes, Walter & Stefania are awesome, but the food is what keeps us coming back. The pizzas and panini are ridiculously delish and we can watch soccer games? Yes please!

Not to mention they show Italian movies Thursday nights - get there early because it's always packed!

Love it.
author: Francesca F.

description: amazing melt in your mouth pizza. thin oven crust pizza... definitely worth it...
author: Sun P.

description:
I'm so torn on how many stars to give Cafe Baonecci.  Their pizza is AMAZING. Hands down the best pizza I've had in the Bay Area.  But, I was also on the receiving end on some of the worst service EVER on my last visit.  I've been here for lunch and enjoyed the pizza & service, but when I came for dinner last Saturday night I was kind of appalled.

But, let's start with the good stuff- THE PIZZA.  They make amazing, crispy thin crust pizza.  On my last visit we had the prosciutto and arugala pizza and the gorgonzola and pear pizza.  They were both fantastic.  The pear pizza gets extra points for looking super cool as well - they take fresh curly strips of pear and throw them on the pizza after it comes out of the oven.  I wasn't 100% sold on gorgonzola on pizza before I had this, but the flavor was great and not too overpowering.

Now on to the bad stuff. First, it took them much longer to seat us than was quoted - not a big deal, happens all the time.  The first strike was after they seated us, we were ignored for at least 15 minutes.  So 30 minutes waiting outside + 15 minutes waiting at the table (totally ready to order - had to entertain ourselves outside somehow) = three hungry ladies.  We finally get to order and asked for the cheese plate plus the two pizzas I mentioned above.  Cheese plate comes out and is delicious - there were 4 kinds of cheese + jam + honey and bread.  We ran out of bread with about half the cheese left so we asked for more.  Instead of getting another serving of bread the size of what we had already eaten, we got about half that.  Really?? I'm pretty sure they give bread out for free to people who don't get the cheese platter so it seems pretty absurd to skimp on that.  We again ran out of bread but just sucked it up and finished the cheese.  Next came the pizzas... and by pizzas I mean pizza.  They brought out one of the pizzas we ordered and some other pizza we didn't order.  When we told them the second one wasn't what we ordered, they took back BOTH pies.  About two minutes later they came back out with the one correct pie.  We ate that (again DELICIOUS) and the second pie came out a few minutes later.  Again, this wouldn't have been a big deal if it had been the one thing that went wrong.

Well, now I have officially gone on a Yelp rant, but as you can see I still gave them four stars.  I think their food is great, I love the atmosphere and I have had good service there before.  I'm going to give Baonecci the benefit of the doubt on this one, but I'll update my review after my next visit!
author: Liz H.

description: EVEN BETTER the 2nd time....*even though* I went with the parentals this time.  And *even though* we HAD to order 3 pizzas, which included tuna & veggie.  And *even though* i HAD to have a fresh strawberry bellini. And *even though* there was only ONE Gambaccini (Gambaccino?) in attendance.... :)  Still lllloved it!!!
author: Amy K.

description:
Almost no baked goods at noon on a Saturday.

I had a piece of focaccia and it was disappointing.  

I'll try to go back for a pizza and upgrade my review if warranted.  It's great that this is family run.  Maybe I was there on the wrong day or at the wrong time.
author: Bay G.

description:
Great crust.  Very thin, light, crisp, occasional whisper of chewiness.  The sauce was simple and tasted intensely of ripe tomatoes.  

Dinner tonight:

Bresaola appetizer 

Monte bianco:  Mozzarella fior di latte, prosciutto, and a dollop of mascarpone in the center.

Rustica:  Mozzarella fior di latte, Prosciutto, baby arugula.

From the specials board:  Mozzarella fior di latte, sausage, white truffle oil, baby arugula.

Couple jugs of wine.

We stayed for a few hours and the service was attentive throughout.
author: A N.

description:
I'll gladly own it: I'm a pizza elitist.  A snob.  I look down my nose at people who eat Domino's.  I've thought about slapping the guy who told me "Roundtable is good pizza, brah!".

I've eaten at some of the best pizza places NYC has to offer...which are found in Brooklyn, not Manhatten..but that's another story for another day..  Anywho....Caffe BaoNecci is the best pizza I've ever eaten, period.

Yes, its different from NYC style, or Chicago style.  This is super thin crust pizza which is what you would expect to find in Naples, or Rome, or Florence.  The ingredients are insanely good which really makes this pizza.

I had the proscuitto, mascapone (best marscapone I've ever eaten), and mozzerella, with san marzano tomato sauce.  Unbelievable.  The marscapone nearly made me pass out.  There is something about watching cold, creamy, marscapone melt over a hot, fresh out of the oven pizza pie.  I'd never had it like that, but oh my god, I would have smeared it all over my body before being licked to death by a thousand stray cats.  

The place had just closed when we got there, but thankfully the owners were willing to throw a couple more pies into the oven for us after we told them we had come all the way from San Diego for their pizza.  This is as good as it gets.  Anyone that says otherwise is a moron.  I'd eat here every day if I could...this place single handedly makes me want to move to San Fran.
author: Matt P.

description:
Great thin crust pizza. One of the best pizza's in the city. I had the truffle salami pizza and it was awesome!

The only downside is that it's a bit pricey for pizza.
author: Tony I.

description: Yum! Went here for dinner - spent about $25 for lasagna and splitting a carafe of house red. They have a pretty decent pizza selection - less pasta but I ended up ordering the lasagna and it was well worth it.  The portion sizes are just perfect - you won't end up taking anything home (unless you are a REALLY light eater) but feel full and content with what you get. I really loved the ambiance of the place the best - it felt like a really old-style pizza place (probably the tablecloths that got me!).  I would recommend for a casual date!
author: Katy G.

description:
OK pizza...
My friends and I thought this place is a bit overated.
You can just run to your local pizzeria next door and can do about same.
author: Nick C.

description:
Wow.  All I can say after my visit here in Friday night.  We literally were teleported to Italy for about an hour while inside the doors here.  Food aside- this experience was absurd.  It was kind of late, 9:30 or so and we weren't sure if this place would still be open.  It was, and there happened to be a group of 10-12 Italians crowded around some tables in the corner.  One of them happened to have a guitar. Q- Who does this guy think he is with a guitar in this restaurant??  A- The life of the party.  I figured he would be playing his favorite dave matthews and kings of leon songs, but we weren't so lucky.  This group proceeded to serenade the entire restaurant with a variety of Italian hits, ranging from opera-esque duets to some Italian countryside sounding songs.  The quality of the singing was just wild.  I think I would have payed money to hear a performance like this.  

So, great vibe.  The owner of the place was our server, suggesting we get the pizza with the chilled mascarpone on top.  We did. It was great.  The bread sticks were also very simply delicious.  Soup and salad were the rest of the meal and filled us up quite nicely.  I don't know if I could ever have a duplicate experience, but I will absolutely try.  This place is a great find in the NB area.
author: William B.

description: Forget all the hype about that other place. Three types of ovens and some fancy award? Please. It's hype. If you're good at your craft you don't need to brag about winning awards from Italians. These guys are Italians. This is the way a pizza is meant to be made. Hands down the best pizza in North Beach.
author: Mark M.

description: Damn good pizza and very cozy environment.
author: Joe V.

description: Not sure why this place has so many stars. The customer service and welcoming attitude are all great aspects. But bland pasta and so-so pizza that's nearly burnt. And the prices don't match the quality / portion. I'm not Italian and I can make better pasta that costs me a buck or two. Maybe most people who rated so highly were drunk lol.
author: Amien P.

description: This is what I've come to adore about the shitty, being feed peasant food for a kings ransom.  Ok haters, here's your "q", three people, three "pizzas", three beers, what did this cost?  140 bucks.  Yeah.  This would be ok if the Caesar salad didn't have crappy bottled dressing and box croutons, shit, I'm sorry, I forgot, it's from "Lucca", lap it up you trend sucking dot.com wannabee's. How's it feel to eat the Zuck's table scraps? A Caprese salad for just shy of 20 bucks better have tomatoes grown by Alice Water's and her band of malcontent hippies.  Save your money and moveon.org
author: Joe W.

description: Loved this place.  All homemade.  Italian tomatoes.  Tender pasta.  Lasagna and the cheese board are highly recommended.
author: N X.

description: Amazing food, worth the wait! Homemade pasta was to die for!!! Pizza is very thin and light and crispy, loved it!!!
author: Brandy H.

description:
Caffe BaoNecci brings an authentic Italian experience to the heart of San Francisco. When you walk into the restaurant you get the sense that this place is real and not just a placebo makeshift italian restaurant. You are being served by the owner and his family which moved from Italy only to open up a shop from what they do best, make food! Even though the food is on the pricier side, it is very delicious. For their pizzas, they serve traditional thin crust pizza with specialty items on them. They even state in their menu that "their pizza is not for the hungry person but for the connoisseur". We had their calzones which were very good. But what I found to be the best on their menu was the pastas. We tried the Baked Al Forna pasta which was excellent. Everyone at our table had wished they ordered that instead of what we ordered. Granted all our meals were great it was just that was even better. 

It is fun to be served by the family who owns it and have our food cooked by the owners wife. Overall it was a great experience and definitely one to try when you check out San Francisco's Italian town.
author: Aron H.

description: Good thin crust pizza! Ate here with a couple of friends, had the Margherita and the 4 Formaggi. Both were very tasty even though it was on a very thin crust. I've never ate thin crust, so can't really compare, but it was pretty good. Afterwards had the dessert pizza, Nutella E Frutta. Yummy!!! Great, friendly service in a very relaxed cozy atmosphere. Did not feel like we were rushed at all and enjoyed our dinner that night. Would like to go again when I'm in the area.
author: Beth L.

description: This place creates delicious everything.  The pizza dough was crunchy yet soft.  Forgot what the soft cheese with tomatoes appetizer was called, DELICIOUS TOO!
author: George V.

description:
Best. Pizza. Ever. 
You have to try the Porcini mushroom and Arugula one! From now on that's all I'm ordering. It's heaven.
author: Margaret G.

description:
I was wondering if it was truly the "Thinnest Pizza". It sure was! Read more below..

Review by a vegetarian--

Interiors are quite nice and airy. The wait staff is pretty good, although serious at times :)

We started off with the Stefania's Salad. Never before has Cheese + Olive Oil + Walnuts + Apples tasted so good! We pretty much cleaned the plate. It is served with a nice little helping of bread, which is sufficient for the salad, but not enough to fill you up. This is good, as the best is reserved for the PIzza

We ordered the Ricciola, which has thinly shaved Zucchini. 

When we got it, it truly was thinly shaved, and looked awesome. Pizza was extremely thin, nice helping of salt, good tomato sauce with cheese and zucchini. 

The ingredients might sound a bit weird together, but it was perfectly balanced, and extremely tasty!

Check out the photo I've uploaded, to get an idea on how really thin the zucchini is. (Haven't done so yet)

For Dessert, we were too full to try any of the true desserts, so we tried their Biscotti and cookies. These were pretty good too. We got a few home as well

Amazing place, good priced wines, and just delicious food.
author: Manish P.

description:
Fantastic menu filled with a bevy of tasty options that melt in your mouth. Winner winner pizza dinner.

An Italian restaurant with a little SF flair. They received high points for reminding me of Europe with the small tables and vibe. Plus it seemed like every waiter I saw was thin with dark hair. The experience really took me back.

We had very good antipasti followed by even better pizza. My party played pizza roulette with our choices and everyone agreed that each dish was great. Love the thin crust! Good service, great food, and a nice vibe.

Unfortunately we played credit card poker for the bill and I lost. Booo!
author: Nick B.

description: I've got inly one thing to say: awsome! The food was amazing. The service very good and it was great value for money!
author: Inma R.

description:
the food was very tasty and authentic, portions very small. we had a party of 4 people ordered 2 antipasti, and 2 pizzas, 5 beers, the bill was $100 plus tip $120. very pricy!
$30 per person for just snaks, way too much to pay.
very friendly staff, but not sure we will be back any time too soon.
author: Nicky M.

description: Solid place for reasonably priced wine, pizza and tiramisu. I was expecting to be blown away by the pizza based on other reviews. However, I found the pizza to be good but not mindblowing. I've definitely had better, more flavorful pizza in NYC.
author: Alicia B.

description: Great pizza and lasagna. Very nice service. One of the best Italian meals I have ever had.
author: dylan d.

description: Absolutely incredible pizza!! Bring your Amex, this place charges $18 for a 10" personal pizza
author: Robert A.

description: This is a true pizza "joint." Don't come dressed up, but expect the best pizza you have ever had (assuming you are a thin crust fan)! We shared about 4 or 5 pizzas for our group and they were all delicious, Because the pizza is so thin, you will eat more than you think (almost 1 pizza per person). Don't worry, it is still good the next day! Also, we arrived with our aging aunt in a walker and they were very accomodating with seating so she could get in and out easily.
author: Sharon R.

description: The salmon pizza was surprisingly good. Simple relaxed interior and great service
author: Alonso A.

description:
Okay finally got the chance to try to Lardo pizza. I almost didn't though...our server said that they didnt makei such a pizza. Luckily, the boss man (I'm assuming) yelled out that he would make it for us. AWESOME.

Had my favorite Eggplant Parmasean again, the Lardo Pizza and a Prosciutto pizza. Washed this all down with a a Prosecco and  Peach Puree cocktail. YUM. 

The Lardo pizza, although it was pretty tasty, was not really my cup of tea. Probably because It's purely fat, and literally melts in your mouth. Personal preference though,everyone else at the table gobbled it up within 10 minutes!
author: lauren j.

description:
Yeah... This is my favorite restaurant in North Beach... 

One of the best tasting pizzas and pastas are from here... Especially the "art work" on the zucchini pizza is just lovely. And, it is "vegetarian-friendly" too.
author: M G.

description:
I hate pizza. I used to work at a pizza place in high school for 2.5 years and that experience has lived with me for the last 15 years.

Baonecci is simply amazing. It isn't like the thick American style pizza that we get from most places. It has beautiful cracker thin crust and really great toppings. The proscuitto with marscapone is one of my absolute favorites. You don't feel heavy after eating this pizza, so you don't get that sick feeling after eating 3 or 4 slices.

Yummmmm is all I have to say. For me, that's hard to say about pizza, but easy to say about Baonecci.
author: sarah m.

description: Excellent cracker thin crust and unique toppings. Has a more casual, "cafe" feel than many of the other places nearby. My husband and I come here often for a low-key weeknight dinner (we live nearby), which is a perfect time to come. Wouldn't recommend if you're looking for a drawn out dinner on a Saturday, or have a group of more than 4 people as it's a small space. Prices are in line for the area, and I haven't been disappointed with anything we've tried.
author: Alison S.

description:
I went on a Sunday afternoon and had a general idea of where the restaurant was ( i was told corner of Grant & Greene) it's one block down the hill just past the alley. Husband and wife own. She cooks and does a FABULOUS job! 
THANK YOU VICTOR THE GREEK 

I wouldn't have know to ask this if my friend had not recommended it, but they have a daily special: just ask what it is (guess it what ever is whipped up for the day )

The food was amazing....We had the soups to start 
Cannelleni bean and minestrone (bean and veggie soups basically ..so tasty and a perfect start to a chilly day)

The a caprese salad-EXCELLANT 
Tomatoes were bursting with flavor..fresh and crisp
 and FINALLY- LASAGNE 
The Lasagne literally melted in my mouth...fabulous blend of cheese and the sauce was perfection. The portion was huge as well! 

We finished with tea and chocolate chip cookies to walk with ...after lunch. Cookies were soft and moist. When we ran out I was sorry I didn't buy more to take home. (just gives an excuse to go back)

It's quaint and friendly!  Several tables but its small, but that's what makes it so much better, like it's your little secret!!!
The staff was so friendly and warm. There seemed to be alot of regulars who strolled in for to-go or coffee as well. 

My friend was skpetical since it wasn't crowded, but by the time we left it was PACKED

can't wait for another "field trip" for adventures in eating!
And definately can't wait for warm weather so we can sit outside and enjoy weather and the food
author: Courtney D.

description:
After trudging around North Beach for an hour looking for a short wait after the Bluegrass Festival in GG park, we sat down here.  I ordered the Pizza Rustica for myself.  

And it was the best Pizza I've ever had.

Move over Enzo's, there's a new pie on the block.

...also got some scrumptious chocolate ice cream desert.
author: Christian B.

description:
For some time now, the owners have revised their hours of operation as well as their "format". They are now focusing on being a restaurant rather than pizzeria and they definitely want to shake their cafe image. I used to be able to go in for a morning or afternoon coffee as in any cafe, but they now insist that we must be dining there to have coffee. I'm pretty sure that in any other restaurant you can go in and order a dessert and coffee (although the waiter might not appreciate it, they'll do it). Their hours of operation are inconvenient and their pricing is a bit high.

All the same, at least the quality of the food is good. It's a shame about the coffee though. They had my favorite outside of Italy.
author: Maria Y.

description:
We rolled into town from LA super-hungry & hoped Yelp would do us right.  Boy did it.  What a great meal, from start to finish!

The Burrata mozzarella ap was amazing.  Any fresher & the water buffalo would have hoofed it out himself!  Based on the reviews, I knew we had to have the super thin crust margherita pizza and it didn't disappoint.  Simple, but so good.  My skinny  wife had the cannellini soup & caesar salad & raved so much I had to taste it, too.  Terrific!  And the tiramisu,  cannoli & cappuccino were the "cherries" on this incredible cake of a meal.  

Gotta say we also loved the fact that their were real Italian speaking patrons surrounding us.  And I thought it was charmingly cool that you literally have to walk thru the working kitchen to get to the bathroom!   Can't wait to go back!
author: Rick B.

description:
This place has the most delicious focaccia I know of.  If you go early in the morning when it's fresh from the oven, it just melts in your mouth. They have vegan focaccia pizza with their flavorful tomato sauce. 

When I go visit people outside SF, I usually take a loaf of their focaccia as a  north beach's delicacy. Heat up in the oven for a few minutes and serve with balsamic and olive oil. Yum!

The owners Walter, Stefania and Elia are super-friendly and nice.

And oh yes, their coffee is good and they know how to foam milk properly.
author: saurabh S.

description: Best pizza I've ever had in my life, including pizza in Italy, NY, etc.  The thin crust is delicious and the toppings were to die for.  We started with a salad which was so fresh and enough to share.  Pretty white table clothes and friendly staff.  I'll be back the next time I'm out in SF.
author: M B.

description:
It's been almost four years since I've been to Italy. I love authentic Italian pizza so much that I would take a trip to Italy just for the pizza. In the meantime, I've searched in vain for authentic Italian style pizza in the U.S. After reading many reviews in my search for a slice of Italy in the U.S., I finally came across Caffe Baonecci, and I knew I just had to try it.

Caffe Baonecci is appropriately located in San Francisco's North Beach district known as Little Italy. It's a tiny speck of a restaurant hidden on the corner of the street and an alleyway, so it's easy to almost miss. Inside are only about 10 tables. The walls are covered with black and white photographs of famous Italians, including Sofia Loren and the like. A flat screen TV played contemporary Italian music videos. The tables had the traditional red and white checkered tablecloths commonly found in trattorias (a casual Italian restaurant). Though the atmosphere was casual, there were little touches of elegance, like real baby poinsettias donned by each table, and glass water carfes.

Perhaps the nicest touch was not the décor, but our host for the evening, the proud Italian owner who is originally from Lucca. His rolling accent and humor filled the tiny space with warmth. We could hear lively Italian conversations coming from the kitchen that gave me the sense that I really could be in Italy. 

We started with Stefania's Salad, which had romaine lettuce, thinly sliced apple, walnuts, and cubes of Swiss cheese, sprinkled with a light vinaigrette. I was pleased by its freshness and quality ingredients. 

By the owner's recommendation, we chose the "Monte Bianco," a combination of Parma ham and Mascarpone that is unique to Caffe Baonecci. The crust was perfectly thin: soft melt-in-your-mouth in the center and slightly crispy on the outside. What I love most about Italian pizza is the thin crust, so thin that you have to fold it in half like a sandwich to eat, and this is exactly how the crust is at Café Baonecci. The ingredients were top-notch: San Marzano tomato sauce and Fior di latte mozzarella. True to Italian pizza, the tomato sauce was spread just thin enough, and not too acidic. It married perfectly with the fresh mozzarella, which is not oily or greasy, and the right amount of chewy. The Parma (Italian cured ham) added a little bit of saltiness. What makes this pizza truly special is the Mascarpone. The pizza arrives hot from the wood oven with a dollop of cold Mascarpone cheese in the center. (Mascarpone is a soft spreadable Italian cheese, a sweeter version of cream cheese). While the pizza is hot, spread the Mascarpone cheese over the pizza and it melts in like butter. I cannot describe in words the deliciousness of this experience in your mouth: the cool buttery Mascarpone contrasting with the warm Mozzarella and blending with the salty Parma. Truly a special pizza. I even dreamed about this pizza later that night. That's how good it is.
author: Kelly S.

description: I have nothing but excellent things to say about BaoNecci. We called ahead sort of late one night and they sat us right away when we arrived. The staff was friendly, polite, and talkative (in a good way). They enjoyed telling us the history of the restaurant and about traditional italian ways of making pizza, I got a lesson on the origins of mozzarella cheese, it was just wonderful. The pizza was incredible. SO GOOD. My date and I only ordered one between us because we thought that would be enough food, and it was - we were full - but it was so incredibly delicious that we wanted another one. And even though BaoNecci's had closed their doors at that point they HAPPILY made us another pizza from scratch. We tried to be polite and considerate when asking, figuring that would be super annoying to have customers order more once you've closed, but they were TOTALLY cool with it!! They made us another perfect pizza and were friendly the whole time. I will DEFINITELY be going back.
author: Jinja R.

description: Meh.  Won't be back.  Might be 100% authentic, but if it's not tasty, what's the point?  Seems like the emperor has no clothes at this place.
author: Jay J.

description:
Stopped by here to grab some pizza, and it was GREAT. The crust is amazing: ultra thing, crispy, everything you could want really. The sauce is sweet, fresh, and there's lots of it!

The atmosphere was pretty cool too. The owners seem to speak nothing but Italian. They were serving Sangria and Cranberry juice, which I  thought was funny.

Good stuff.
author: Jason C.

description: Authentic Italian! First time here and not only was the food fantastic, but so was the customer service. Made me feel as if I were back in Tuscany.
author: Shelly K.

description: This place is legit!  Run by an Italian family with the mother picking out the ingredients each day, the father running the dining room, and the sons as waiters.  My Italian mother-in-law almost cried saying this pizza was the closest thing she had had to her mother's since coming to North America.
author: Lindsey I.

description:
The best thin crust pizza my wife and I have ever had!!! Being originally from the east coast we've had our share. But, none can compare to this!

We ordered the MonteBianco... a absolute MUST TRY!!!! From the first bite, there were no words. Just BIG eyes and head nods - oh yeah!!!!
author: Craig W.

description:
This place is great.  Run by the owners, you walk in to a little slice of real italy.  Don't be intimidated by the nonstop italian flying all over the place; everybody speaks English too.  You can hang out to watch the latest Italian soccer game, or sit outside and watch the hung-over folks stumble by.  

The coffee here is good enough to keep me coming back, and everyone who works there is awesomely nice.  Their breakfasts taste like home made (probably because they ARE and are made in the back) and the foccacia is seriously rediculous.  Try the veggie one and make sure they heat it up for you (don't worry they'll offer!).  

Last but not least... the coookies.  AHHH so damn good it hurts sometimes.  I walk by here every day on the way home; sometimes I just avert my eyes so i don't tempt myself again and again!!

All in all it's freaking great.  Good food, wonderful people, and a vibe that keeps you coming.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Ho conosciuto tutta la BaoNecci Crew, originaria di Firenze,
e come spesso capita in Italia,
chi gestisce il locale ne e' anche proprietario.

La pizza e' una bomba,
l'atmosfera accogliente,
la gente divertente.

Passate di qua,
se volete respirare un po' d'Italia fresca.

A presto Amicici Necci!
author: Meli M.

description: nice italian restaurant - i recommend the diavola pizza. 3-stars because i'm not blown away, but i might go back if im in the area. lovers of thin crust pizza will really enjoy this place.
author: Rachel S.

description: Possibly the best Italian meal I have ever eaten.  The only other meal that can compare is Carmen's in the North End of Boston.  The menu is short, the meals are simple and everything that my family had was spectacular.  Do yourself a favor and visit this hidden gem.
author: Jeff P.

description: Great thin crust pizza and pasta.  Had the Salamino.  Very nice to still be family owned and run.  Small place but we got in right away on a Friday night.
author: Brian L.

description: Charming and cozy place. The pizza's are delicious- don't miss the truffle salame pizza!
author: Sara M.

description: We picked this place based on the strength of its Yelp reviews.  I liked the non-touristy, neighborhood vibe.  We started with a glass of wine and a cheese plate - both were very good.  We then ordered pizzas.  Clearly, the ingredients were fresh and of high quality, but this just isn't my style of pizza.  The crust was impossibly thin, which means that the edges were cracker-like in their crispiness.  I like a little more chew to my pizza crust - even on a neapolitan-style pie.  (See www.pupatella.com to see what I'm talking about)  We skipped the dessert pizzas, fearing a dessert cracker.  Not sure I would return.
author: Ryan W.

description: We are not sure why this restaurant gets high reviews. The pizza is like a cracker with cheese on it. Lots of wine choices!  The service is nice. Grandma cooks everything fresh in the kitchen.  It's a small place so make sure to make a reservation.
author: Sue P.

description: Simple, delicious food. Had the margherita pizza and pesto pasta and loved them both. Pizzas are thin crust and not too heavy. Ambience is very casual.
author: Viv M.

description:
came over the 4th time...just as great as the first time!!!!!

try their house wine (red) from their granparent's vineyard (?) it will go well with anything you have here, and if you're celebrating something special, order a bottle of
Brunello  Di Montalcino ($85)...you'll love it
author: Martin C.

description: I would like to update everyone. In May I traveled through Europe and when in Italy, I ordered Pizza (of course) and I must say that Caffe Baonecci is still my favorite pizza. Taste pure authentic!!!
author: Mariam B.

description: Was it bad? nah... Was it worth it? Hell no!  Way too expensive for what you get... Pizza was OK, salad, meh... wine - tasted like from a box. They got some nerve charging $17 for a flimsy-ass pizza. Never returning... Seriously, much better and cheaper pizza and other food in the area.
author: Tom M.

description:
One of the best THIN crust pizzas I've ever tried. With family friends who wanted pizza so bad, and found this place, so we got in and were greeted by the friendliest camerieri, ever.

Fresh, thin, simple, amazing. For all those thin crust fanatics out there, you guys should give this place a go.
author: Carlos G.

description: Quite possibly the best Italian food I've had in SF. From beginning to end starting with the caprese salad, to the Rustica pizza, to a dessert of chocolate gelato and espresso  everything was fantastic. I highly recommend this small mom and pop restaurant to fulfill all your Italian cravings!
author: Jessica M.

description: Once you get a slice.... You can't help it but to go back... :P I feel like I am eating pizza in Italy
author: Rouzbeh N.

description: Ran into this place randomly and all but two tables were reserved so we figured it had to be good....it was amazing! Recommend the pear pizza and pear salad!
author: Suzy C.

description:
Awesome. 

If you like thin crust pizza this is about as thin and crunchy as it gets. A triumph!
author: Sammy N.

description: Found this through yelp.  Didn't look like much from the outside when we arrived, but the food was awesome.  great service and fun people working the place.  Definitely worth visiting
author: Connie S.

description: We came here to try their thin, flatbread pizzas, (we have our special place that we go since two years in mill valley) and we were not disappointed. The food is great, the pizzas are simple yet very good.  The atmosphere is nice and the owner, Walter, and his son are the nicest people ever.
author: Seto T.

description: This place gets a five star for their pizza but a 4 star for decor and service.  Ordered their pizza and salad.  I ordered their prosciutto with arugula pizza.  It was awesome.  YUMMY!!!!!  One of best thin crust pizzas I've ever had.  Our salad was not so good.  I would probably never order salad from this place ever again.  Our waiter was this cute Italian man.  His service was okay but not great.  This is a very casual sit down restaurant.  Nothing spectacular about their decor. All in all, I would return.  Their awesome pizza makes all the other not so great aspects seem not such a big deal after all.
author: Annie L.

description: thin crispy crusted, simple ingredients, seriously delicious pizzas!
author: Maithy T.

description: After a wicked flight featuring an airplane interior redolent with the smell of baby vomit (with an accompanying chorus of several adults), all Mrs. Grampy and I wanted to do on the next night was find an Italian ristorante that had the simple essentials nailed, basically a trattoria. This is the place. White beans with pasta, served with deliciously elegant salads, then followed by the most amazing cannoli we've ever enjoyed. Great new memories, but sad since they're 2200 miles away and there ain't a thing like this in Atlanta.
author: George C.

description:
To begin, my husband, daughter & I have eaten here several times and continually recommended BaoNecci to one & all we know.  It has always SEEMED to be a quintessential neighborhood spot, even though tourists do seem to find it.  
Never have we been asked if we had reservations & never have we needed them- if there are no tables avail, we just checked in with the staff and waited inside (its tiny!) or outside for one to clear. 
Last Saturday, approx 6:30 pm we walked in and were asked "do you have reservations?" ( we have NEVER been asked this) when there were 2 tables of 4 vacant. We asked about those tables and were told they were for people who had reservations at 7:15-- 45 min later!  We asked if we could sit there and order our pizzas in the mean time ( we knew what we wanted) - they said no. 
The weirdest part is that they didn't tell us how long we could wait for another table ( as in putting your name in etc) they tried to shoo us out the door. Additionally- while we were trying to figure out this reservation/table thing several other parties came to see if they could get a table and were told NO if they didn't have reservations. Unless you're Gary Danko, what kind of restaurant doesn't let you wait for a table- even outside??  
Something has changed here- and it isn't good. There are plenty of trattorias in SF~ enough said.
author: DH H.

description:
The place
Nothing to speak of, small off the main street store front.  Not grungy enough to be called a dive, more like a neighborhood staple.  The kind of place you'd expect to find in NYC's Little Italy or Boston's North End.  The mother and father run the restaurant with one or more of the kids helping out now and then.  They take pride in their food and if given the chance, will talk your ear off.  If you speak Italian (which I don't) you'd be in ever better company.

The food
The kids ordered by the slice, and their slices were quite good looking and plenty of size there for the adults too.  However the real star was the pizza that my wife and I ordered, and it was an absolute revelation.  The Monte Bistro pizza with the marscapone cheese added cold after the pizza cooked was amazing.  The starter minestrone soup was fantastic as well, really cutting through the damp chill that one can pick up on an evening perusing the streets of San Fran.  The desserts were also fantastic with the kids ordering a few pastries from the counter case and the wife and I splitting a fresh, homemade, cannoli.  I felt that I was insulting them when we said we couldn't take the last few slices of pizza with us ... just like I would at my mom's house.

The bottom line
This was one of the best dining experiences we had while on our trip.  The small family run operation was a treat.  The only knock, which wasn't worth taking a star away for, was the TV which was showing the Italian equivalent of American Idol.  It entertained for about 5 min, then became annoying.  Not so much so to ruin the experience, but enough that I noticed.
author: Gregory L.

description: For my money, the best thin-crust crispy delicious pizza in San Francisco, served by a friendly family in a relaxing space.  I'm absolutely addicted to the Parma pizza!
author: Christian C.

description: Best thin-crust pizza I've ever tasted.  Rome, Manhattan, Tony's down the street...none of them compare.  All of the pizzas are amazing, but the Montebianco pizza is literally the best single thing I have tasted all year.  Amazing.  I usually get takeout on my way home, but the service is nice and friendly if you are eating at the restaurant.  Seems like a real family restaurant, which makes the experience all the more enjoyable.
author: Zac A.

description: May 2012: Wanted to find a place off the beaten path where locals go. The pizza is good but be advised that the restaurant is VERY small, you will be bumped into by both customers and staff. By the way, the staff is incredible, we could have done without the boom box radio going on as well.
author: Jon U.

description: Best lasagna dish hands down. Couldn't ask for a better eating experience. Food 5 stars. Service 5 stars. Ambiance 5 stars.
author: Luiz D.

description: At last, a  Neapolitan thin-crust pizza that's baked flaky and crispy on the bottom with no exaggerated overblown crown. This is the best pizza in the Bay Area. The other fare here is excellent, too.  Bellissimo.
author: Gasper S.

description: Wonderful 'true' Italian style thin crust pizza. Family run and the owner is VERY hospitable.  Try the truffle salame pizza - amazing! House white wine was ho hum, but it's house wine. It's small so call ahead for large parties and reservations on the weekends.
author: Mike L.

description: This restaurant will transport you to a small town in Tuscany, as the family that runs and staffs it provide an experience typical of their home (near Lucca).  Service was friendly and prompt, and the thin crust pizza and hand-made pasta excellent.  Salads were perfectly dressed and are huge -- you may want to split one.  The wine selections were good and very well priced, just like a true Italian restaurant.  The flavors are typical of the Lucca region, although the menu branches out to other areas.
author: Greg K.

description:
I was walking around North Beach with a friend and we wanted some yummy authentic italian lunch. unfortunately, it didn't happen for us :(
We walked in and everybody was friendly, the decor is ok. We wanted to share a pasta and a salad. We ordered the pasta puttanesca. When we got it, it didn't look it so we nicely informed the waiter that it must be someone else's dish. He apologized but returned with the same pasta telling us, that it was the right one after all. 
We started eating but it tasted like pasta with tomato sauce and not a very flavorful one. We missed the anchovies, the capers, the whole nine yards.
We kindly told the waiter once again that he must have made a mistake but then he informed us that because capers and the anchovies have a very strong flavor profile and most people don't like them, they don't put it in the puttanesca pasta. Seriously???!!!
Then why call it puttanesca??!! He took our pasta back and asked the cook to put in some anchovies and capers to it (hopefully nothing else naughty). The pasta was still blend, though. oh well! lesson learned. never again lunch here.
author: Oyo S.

description: Neat little Italian restaurant. Had a pepperoni/sausage pizza. Crust was light and airy. Very tasty. Wife and kids had the pasta el pesto and lasagna. The pasta is hone made and was amazing! Service was excellent. Would definately recommend! Wanted to get the tiramasu but didn't have room!
author: David T.

description: Friday. Knight I. Had the pleasure to have dinner at. Bao. Necci  and the experience was a reminder of my. Native city of. Lucca Toscany and just happen that they are from there. The owners husband and wife with 2 son make you feel like you are home the service is excellent with a great wine list at great prices the menu is base on dishes that I remember so well as a child .The pizza is Thin. Crust. one of the things that I like the best because they are very creative on the products they use and the understanding of Italian cooking..Other dishes are authentic  from old recipe passed down from family .great atmosphere with friendly family environment and good value  Good place to try
author: Giovanni L.

description: Came here to try the famous thin crust dessert pizza. My friend has been raving about this place for its dessert pizza and I could never understand what that is. Wouldn't it just be like a crepe?? Well, it basically is as tasty as one....except it's on a crunchy thin pizza crust instead of the pancake like batter. The nutella is awesome, and anything mixed with strawberries, bananas, and nutella has got to be amazing. Service is also really great. Will definitely need to come back to try the other pizzas on the menu.
author: Louisa L.

description:
I still enjoy Baonecci and the nourishing food (see my earlier review for details), but the prices have dramatically increased beyond the level of service and atmosphere. I must remind myself that this is now priced similarly to any other $$-$$$ place in the city, and hence visit occasionally and with awareness, rather than treat it as a go-to lunch stop. 

Baonecci is now rather expensive for what one receives, yet the tv still blares Italian pop and aspects of the experience are still self-serve, like at a cafe. For regular restaurant prices I want the full experience, including elegant or interesting music, not cheap Italian pop blaring from a flatscreen, which interferes with conversation or study. I previously tolerated the music and cafe atmosphere because the prices used to be equally casual, and because the restaurant began as a neighborhood cafe that served home-style food. However, when paying $35 for lunch (per person; well, my friend ordered way more than me and we split the bill nonetheless) I don't want to feel jarred by grating music, and pay $2 for more bread. Do they want to be a cafe or a restaurant? Now it's priced as the latter, but still retains a few too many aspects of the former, given the cost. Regardless, I always wished that they would choose less jarring, cheap music, which would enhance, rather than detract, from the atmosphere.
author: Eliza S.

description:
I was looking for a non-touristy yet affordable place to eat in North Beach and I found BaoNecci.

GOOD:
- This place doesn't get super crowded like many other places in North Beach. I had no problem getting a table for 4 people at 7:00PM on a Friday evening. 
- The Baonecci Monte Bianco pizza was somewhat on the light side. The mascarpone cheese is kind of dolloped in the middle so you don't really get that much of it. It adds a creamy note to the pizza. The pizza was very light and I was expecting something more flavorful because it is named after the establishment. 
- The California Pepperoni pizza (my friends wanted it okay) was surprisingly good. The salami on top was delicious and the pizza had more sauce on it, similar to American style pizza (but not THAT much sauce).
- The service is very friendly. You feel like you stepped into someone's kitchen as opposed to a restaurant.

JUST OKAY:
- You have to walk through their kitchen to get to the restroom. Some people might be turned off by that but I thought it was cool to see the kitchen.
- The pizzas are not that cheap ($11-16) if you are hungry. The pizzas are super thin crust so if you are starving, one pizza is enough for only one person. 
- The decor is minimal and bare. It might be too casual for a first date but if you don't care about decor, don't worry about it.

CONCLUSION:
- BaoNecci is a nice gem in North Beach. It is easy to walk past this place without noticing its existence because it looks more like a bakery than a sit-down place to eat. However, if you are looking for some lighter Italian-style pizza that is not loaded with cheese and sauce like American pizza, this is the place. They also make their pizza with super thin crusts for all you non-crust lovers out there.
author: Alex P.

description:
ever since i came back from brooklyn over the summer, i have been searching for sf pizza that could rival ny's. i found it. not only are the owners of baonecci incredibly friendly and helpful, but they bake some extremely good products. their assortment of baked italian goods is diverse and large, and since i did not have much background in this cuisine, i decided to ask about what each kind of food was. the proprietors were so patient and helpful as i pestered them about their paninis, polenta, and almond tarts.

of course, i was eyeballing their cheese pizza, which i eventually got a slice of. it was $3, which is kind of expensive, but i decided that they entirely deserved 5, not 4, stars due to the quality of the service and the food. this cheese pizza was incredible: a very thinly made crust that did not fall apart and was not bland in taste, really flavorful fresh tomato sauce, simple crushed basil leaves, and a very hot, oozing cheese that was not overly salty. this is some good fare.
author: Danny C.

description: 1 star food.   5 star service, but that doesn't matter when the food sucks.  They get away with this because they are so close to Columbus street.
author: Mike R.

description:
I am pretty tough to please when it comes to pizza. I have even changed my idea of a great pizza. I am good with a standard NY style slice with fresh ingredients, but I am starting to lean toward the thin crusts...especially after eating here. 

We read the reviews while visiting SF, and wanted something a bit more authentic than the normal places. We were really surprised by pizza. My daughter had the pepperoni & sausage (probably the best one), and my wife and I had the mushroom (fancier name, but I forget what it was), and the tomato/basil pizza. I am now searching all of LA for a place that has crispy crust like BaoNecci. The reason that I gave it 5 stars was the great thin crust, phenomenal pepperoni & sausage pizza, and the service was really friendly. 

I can't wait to go back.
author: Rick T.

description:
Wow!  Not sure what I can say that others have not but I have to say something.  We were looking for something new, different and flavorful and we found it: BaoNecci!

First thing the wife said to me as we all sat down is "Sitting here lets me feel as if I'm in Italy."  And she was right.  The scent of pizza was wonderful.  Luckely we were seated right away.  Though we always arrive early out of respect for the non-kid-in-tow crowd that comes a little later.  

Asked the waiter what to order and he said Rustica.  So we didn't listen and ordered:

Monteblanco pizza - Fantastic!!!  What a refreshing flavor after all the heavy pizzas around the bay.  They put wafer thin Italian ham on top along with a touch of sour cream.  Perfect!   We ate that pizza in less than two minutes and then ordered:

Meat Lasagna:  Again, wonderful!  The entire family loved it and kids finished off the last of it in no time so we finally decided to listen to the experts and ordered:

Rustica:  Ok, three perfect dishes!  unreal.  Talk about great flavor.  

Some side notes:  Ask for the bread.  Its actually pizza dough sliced up with a little salt and olive oil.  Very good.

Cesar salad was very fresh and had a wonderful dressing.  Though I would have liked a little less.....but very minor detail.

As a total bonus there is a cool little natural/organic grocery store right around the corner from this place.  :)  Love those little stores.

Yes, we will be back and we'll bring friends.   

Arrive early or you'll wait.  But trust me, its worth the wait!!

Oh, service was friendly, fast, and informative.  You really get the feeling your eating in someones home.  Very kind family business.


Enjoy!
author: LeftCoast Y.

description:
LOVE IT, LOVE IT AND LOVE IT MORE
never was a pizza fan, but always wanted to try the real authentic pizza..
the thinest crust, fresh tasty tomato sause, with mystery italian rap, really feel like i just walked in a small rest. in Italy.
We went there to early, they won't even set up for dinner yet, but they were kindly recommended us some awesome food. i think i am hocked. We'll be back SOON!
author: Sisi W.

description: I had the most amazing pizza at this place. Honestly, I don't recall anywhere that came even close to this place in my many years in California.
author: George L.

description:
A great neighborhood place.  The outdoor seating is really lovely on a sunny day.  It doesn't get overly crowded like Cafe Trieste.  Many patrons walk in and start speaking Italian, it feels right and at someone's home.
