We have tried their pizza - thin crust, simple but flavorful.  Focaccia sandwich - it's really hard to say no especially the ham and mozzarella cheese.  They will happily heat them up for you if you are eating there.  The staff behind the counter is always very friendly and ready to help.

We also got their little Ladies Kisses to bring to some friends and they loved it.  The chocolate ones had vanilla cream and the vanilla cookie had the chocolate cream.  So dainty, perfect to pop in the mouth as snack.

Check it out if you are in the neighborhood, they will greet you warmly like you are a regular.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I love this place.  We split a pizza and it was so good we ordered another.  I don't write many reviews, esp of Italian restaraunts 'cause so many are similar.

But this place is different.  The feeling is different.  My girl and I looked at each other and thought  "we scored"
author: Kevin D.

description: Pizza was good but the crust a little bit too crispy for me. I tried pizza margherita and mushroom ham pizza. Good for mid day snack.
author: Anuj K.

description:
In addition to L'Osteria Del Forno, Bao Necci is the other authentic Italian (not Italian-American) restaurant in North Beach.

A family run business, Sofia does most, if not all, of the cooking.

Two of my favorites are the antipasti with fagioli (beans) - both are great. Enough for 2-4, I've often had one as my meal - and taken leftovers home.

The panini are the most authentic you will get in North Beach. I'm partial to the tonno (tuna).

I rarely get past the antipasti and salads when alone; and often we'll have pizza when I'm there in groups.

The pizzas are thin style. Highly recommended for a group of 3 or more, who will be getting at least 2-3 pizzas, end with the Contadina. Thin slices of pears and light gorgonzola (in addition to the standard mozzarella and parmesan) on thin crust pizza.
author: Tom N.

description: On a scale of 1-10 (10 being the best) I give the pizza a 7. My son who ordered the calzone gave it a 1 because the top of the calzone was burnt black! I don't blame him. They never should have brought it to the table. We will not return
author: Juanette H.

description: Easily one of the BEST pizzas I've ever had. I never knew what REAL authentic Italian pizza was until I tried this! If you live in SF you need to come here!
author: Jeremy B.

description: Its tough to please the snobby foodies.who love all things authentically Italian,but  Bao Necci might have pulled its way to number one on ourbest pizza in the city. First and foremost, the waiters are ridiculous looking. (Yes, that counts for a 1/2 a star) Great glasses of Montonaldo. To start: Prosciutto w/ melon arugula salad with burata. The Melon was perfume. Pizza: with truffle oil, ham and topped with arugula. Yes, that's Italian! Dessert: (yes, had room) lemon gelato: perfecto!
author: Janet P.

description: Family run, wonderful restaurant.  We orderd two pizzas initially but every pizza we tried was so good we decided to be gluttenous and ordered a 3rd pizza.  The speck pizza with pears shaved on top was to die for.  Because everything we had was so good we decided to sit there longer to let our stomach settle and order 3 desserts.  The desserts were just as good.  Lucky we walked from our hotel to the restaurant because we need to walk off the meal.
author: Tammy P.

description:
Loved this place!!! Here's why:

The Food: Awesome, very authentic Italian. My bf, a couple friends and I went here because we recently were in Tuscany and wanted to find somewhere in the city that transported us back - this was it! The calzone and pizza was so yummy - fresh ingredients, thin/light crust, you can tell it was homemade, fresh out of the oven. Another friend ordered one of their specials - polenta lasagna - YUM! Like traditional lasagna, but not as heavy.

The Place: So cute! In an old victorian - very home-y feeling. The walls are covered with pictures of the family and customers, which makes you feel the love. The people inside were all talking Italian - definitely added to the experience.

The People: So nice! Everyone working was family and treated you like you were part of the family too. And their oldest son, who was our server - cute!

A little tip - Thursday nights they play Italian movies while you eat at around 7p.

Enjoy!
author: Jesse V.

description: Decent, not awesome. Shocked at the outstanding reviews. Maybe I've lived here too long to think this place is amazing. Pasta was swimming in sauce. Table had a dirty film on it. Ambiance better than bleak, certainly not festive. Meh.
author: gina p.

description: Best italian pizza in America. I LOVED their food and will come back to eat more
author: Natalie W.

description: Loved it!! The staff is all family members and I got a hug from Mom when I left. Pizza is awesome.
author: Phamus F.

description:
If you're a lucky American kid, and you get to go to Italy one of the first things you notice about the food is how familiar, and yet foreign it is. That's almost too obvious a statement, but when you're raised on peanut butter and jelly sandwiches made with sliced wheat bread your first sampling of an Italian panino can be a tricky experience.

For me, I felt like I had too many choices before me, and none really good. (Looking at a case of panini) Open faced, looks like some combination of tuna, mayo, and peas-WTF? Next, prosciutto crudo, that means raw ham? Next, and on and on. I learned how to order prosciutto cotto and pretty much left it at that.

Then you go back to Italy a little older, and this time some strange impulse moves you to order the bizarre sandwich with the peas in it. This panino, and many that follow change your life. You bust through the American palette barrier, and you'll never again hold a Subway or a Quizno's in high esteem.

Back home panini have become very popular, and they are good but they are also familiar and unforeign to me. Then, about one month ago I noticed that Danilo looked a little different than it used to, and I walked in to see what's up. There are some nice new owners, who have moved the bakery cases around, and whoa! there they were! Panini only an Italian could make - giant wedges of impossibly thin focaccia. Toppings like tuna, capers, tomato and mayo, or ham, mushroom, and melted provolone. Tomato basil, olive oil, and mascarpone.

I ordered the tuna panino. The tuna is used almost like a condiment to lightly add flavor to the real star of the show-perfectly flavored tomatoes, and the capers add the right amount of zing. I ate the sandwich while walking down Green Street, and when I finished I turned around and walked straight back into Danilo and ordered the ham and mushroom sandwich. Same result, goodness.

Now, any time I walk near Green Street between 11 a.m. and 6 p.m., I  go to Danilo. Little by little they are adding to the menu, pizzas by the slice can be had as well. The space is still filling in, but I'm looking forward to the day when their panini case is stacked high with strange combinations. I will try them all.
author: Greg L.

description: Had a wonderful dinner at this delightful restaurant.  Hubby and I shared the apple and cheese salad - light and tasty.  We also shared an order of lasagne and a pizza that had sausage and thin sliced onions - all ingredients were fresh, light and even homemade pasta for the lasagne noodles.  We ended our evening with tiramisu and cannoli.  All was so good and tasty.  Our waiter was the owners son, and was friendly, nice and we really liked him.  The owner (Dad) came over and chatted with us.  We loved this place and will be back.  A good idea to have reservations.
author: D C.

description:
I've been to Italy 18 times, taken to the most rustic establishments in the outskirts of town by locals, and eaten sublime pizza (with a fork and knife of course.) The key to delicious pizza is not quantity, but quality. Something America usually does very different from Europe.

Here at BaoNecci, you have a thin pizza. Why? Because thick, American-style pies loaded with cheese and meat makes you fat, that's why. A thin crust calls for less toppings. But a few slices of authentic aged prosciutto and good cheese are all you need. Just enough to create that music in your mouth.

Bravo to the owners on their success in staying true to thin Italian pizza. This is the only place I've found in the Bay Area that serves such a pizza. Family run shop is a good experience. I enjoyed how they brought out water in the tall glass bottles with the flip top. Just like in Italia. Get the Monte Bianco and Contadina pizzas. Also, do try the espressos/cappuchinos. Italian coffee is always the best.
author: Anthony L.

description: Wonderful pizza!!!! Something I hugely miss while living in LA.   Will be back every time when in town (after getting torn up at Toronado at the other side of town)
author: Armenoid B.

description: Found the place on yelp, wasn't disappointed. Place felt authentic when we walked in. We were seated right away at a nice table. Order the Stefania Salad, excellent, had romaine, apples, walnuts. Also order the mortadella, pesto, sun dried tomato panini, very delicious, bread was unique and crispy. Our main course was the pizza with prosciutto and arugula, also delicious! Try this place you'll be pleasantly surprised.
author: Gustav A.

description: I've been coming here for a while now and finally leaving my review. This place is really great. The Margherita pizza, baonecci salad(goat cheese and pears), tiramisu and cappuccino are my favorite here. The pizza is uniquely thin and just so very flavorful, yet doesn't make me feel bloated like other pizzas. The decor is very simple but I come for the food! Yum
author: Daniel A.

description:
Do I love Danilo because a trip there makes a super pleasant stroll (uh, can it be a stroll if it leaves you panting?) from my office? Because of the burly, gruff-yet-sheepish Italian dude at the counter who doesn't really speak or understand much English? Because it manages to convince me that a lunch of focaccia (bread) and cookies (more bread) is like totally balanced? Or maybe because it's cheap and yum? 

All I know is that this place would totally get 5 stars if they hadn't once charged me $3.50 for a slightly-soggy undersized cannoli and if crazy annoying shit didn't always happen to me when I'm trying to eat my potato focaccia and drink my mineral water and eat my rice fritter in the nearby park:

-Me and B-- were just sitting on a bench eating carbs and mind out own business when an old woman walked up to our bench and started staring us down. She looked us up. She looked us down. She decided that we were too tough for her and she walked over to the next bench. But woman, she keeps staring at us! More at B--, really. For like 15 minutes. Even when there's way more interesting shit to watch, like some road rage happening directly in front of us in the street and Italian men leaning out their windows yelling stuff at each other in Italian. Maybe she's staring at B-- 'cause she thinks that there's only room for one Asian person in the park and that's her. I dunno. B-- is uncomfortable, so I tell him to stick his tongue out at her. Like, in a dirty way. He had crumbs and stuff all over his tongue, but it totally worked.

-Street person with a bleeding ulcer comes up to B-- and A-- and me and asks us if we're in college. "Uh no." THEN he starts singing Christmas carols to us. Well, ONE Christmas carol. It's fucking October. And the Christmas carol takes about 9 minutes for him to get through because he takes these extraordinarily long pauses between the verses. Plus, it's that fucking "Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire" song. I hate that song. Also, there's a man in running shorts and no shirt wearing a werewolf mask running around the park.
author: Ben P.

description: Fantastic place. Made me feel as if my semester abroad in Rome had never ended. High quality ingredients come together in inventive combinations that both honor and explore the tradition of its creators. Talking with Stefania is like sitting in a kitchen in a small Tuscan town. I had a pizza with wild boar salami (cinghale) and mushrooms. Perfetto.
author: Padraic M.

description: We arrived exactly on time for a table we booked at 6.30pm, ordered a salad and a couple of pizzas. The salad arrived when expected but by 7.20pm we still hadn't received our pizzas. After some gentle prompting they arrived and were great. The service was otherwise good.
author: Adrian B.

description: Cute little place. The pizza was good. I like the thin crust ones. I wished I could eat more but I was full. The service was ok. Price can be a little high but it's a great place to hang out with the girls and talk while having pizza and wine.
author: Nokie N.

description: Smallish, lovely joint with thin crust single size pizza that is not overly crusty, cheesy or saucy.  This italian-family run restaurant will please you if you're looking for relaxed kick back pizza place with delicious food.  Pleasant waiters.  Great dessert menu also!
author: Jim L.

description: This place is a win win. great house wine and amazing pizza!  It is family owned and operated and is a little gem of a restaurant.
author: Vanessa L.

description: When we come to San Francisco, a trip is not complete without visiting Caffe BaoNecci.  Absolutely seriously.  We read somewhere "with impossibly thin pizza crust".  It is our long standing comment...it IS impossibly thin.  But, Caffe BaoNecci can be proud.  This is just like pizza in Italy!  Incredible taste.  And you feel an Italian vibe with the ambience and service.  The incredibly welcoming, friendly (and handsome!) Gambaccini brothers work the front of the house, while mom and dad work the back.  Truly a family operation.   The whole menu reads authentic from the antipasti, pasta dishes and, of course, pizza.  Oh, and don't forget the huge Italian beer list!  Okay, can't say enough.  Go, go, go.  And then, go back!  It is an "impossibly" great experience.
author: James M.

description: It wasn't perfect by any means. They seem put out and hesitant when you say you don't have a reservation (even though it was early and only one other table was occupied). I noticed this happen with everyone else that came, none had a reservation and everyone got the same treatment (from both hosts). They definitely we're not welcoming. It took quite a while to get our drink order taken. We were fully ready to order by the time they came for that. They serve water at room temperature (no exaggeration) with no ice which was kind of weird. The host/server got more friendly through our visit. The wild boar salami pizza was awesome, from the crust to the sauce to the cheese and salami. You can't beat it. The other pizza we had came with a pear topping and we weren't as crazy about it but it was decent.
author: Curtis H.

description: I would rate the food a 5! The pesto pasta was homemade, delicious! Unfortunately, the service did not match the food - service was slow, inattentive. I had to ask for water, ask for them to serve my wine - after waiting 10 minutes, ask for bread - yikes! But, despite all that, I will go back the next time I am in SF for the food!
author: Joan A.

description: Food was great! Real Italian food! I have the 4 cheese pizza, delicious. My husband had pasta agle olio! He loved it! The staff very friendly. Recommend!
author: Caterina M.

description:
All of you, it seems, were fooled by the sentimental family info in the menu, and the heavy Italian accent the servers layer on to make you think this is good Italian food. Yes, the pizza was fine, but it was not worth $17 per individual-sized pizza! The crust is super thin, since that's their angle, but its also floppy and weak compared to real Italian crusts: most of the toppings just slide off. About 1/3 of my crust shattered into charcoal when I picked it up since it was so thin and burned to a crisp on the edges of one side of the pizza.

The toppings were good, although the prosciutto is some kind of budget-variety meat which is closer in flavor and texture to thinly sliced deli ham or mortadella. The family-friend's wine mentioned in the menu was bad for $34 (maybe it should have cost more like $22-$24 at the most marked-up restaurant prices), and the server brought a 2009 despite the menu listing a 2008. I should have corrected him, so that was my fault.

In any case, the mediocrity and high prices of BaoNecci set off an evening of debates within our group about how it could happen that the masses and Yelp's algorithms could be so wrong. (Probably it is the masses). This restaurant frustrated me to the point that I wanted to start a Yelp account to warn you. I have until now just been a consumer of the otherwise informative reviews of other restaurants in the Market St. and Berkeley areas.

I'm not going to give this place a very low 1-2 star rating despite being annoyed: it deserves a solid 3 stars and the atmosphere is comfortable. But there is some crazy network effect going on here: everyone on Yelp (tourists?) flocks to this place and it certainly doesn't deserve the 4.5 stars that it has at the time of my post.
author: Paul S.

description: Very good all around food.   Pizza was super thin and tasty.   Pasta with pesto was great.   Cheese appetizer was interesting.  Bruschetta was great.  Cannoli was very good though not sweet at all.  Waiter was attentive (and gave our kids complimentary gelato) but rest of staff not so much.   Prices seemed a bit high - surprised this is not a three $ instead of two.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Hands down the best authentic Italian pizza joint in the City! Can't miss this.
author: David O.

description:
Walter & Stefania shut it down at this gem in North Beach! Pop in for cafe and a pizza or stay for calcio and cacciatore & polenta.

Simply delicious.
author: Daniela F.

description: The pizza has a super thin crust, so a 13" isn't really going to fill up the average person.  It was really good though!  Eggplant parm was also good.  And they import San Benedetto peach iced tea that is THE BOMB!  I'm going to try to get some at home.  It is a little spendy for what it is, but considering the real estate, it's normal.
author: Magic M.

description: very nice owners.  simple place.  good value.  great burratta.  just don't have high-quality pizza dough or pizza ovens - and you can taste the difference
author: nick g.

description: We stumbled upon this place while trying to figure out where to go for dinner as the place we intended to go was closed for New Year's Eve.  We knew we were at the right place as soon as we walked into the restaurant. The restaurant is small and unassuming.  Fluid Italian conversation flow between our waiter and the patrons.  The pizza was WOW!  It was the best pizza I have ever had.  The sauce was fresh and homemade.  The crust was thin, smokey and crisp.  I wish I can give this place more stars but alas 5 is the limit.
author: Paul T.

description:
It took me 3 months of walking by this place every morning to walk inside, and am I glad I did. It's like stepping into Italy in the US. It's pretty authentic. I haven't seen panini like this since I left Italy.

I come here for lunch A LOT. I love it. The soups, panini, pizza, and little chocolatie sweet biscuits (cookies)are excellent, especially their florentines. The coffee here is among the best in North Beach. The service is great, and while you wait you can refresh your rusty high school Italian language skills.
author: MissSkip Z.

description: OMG! Am I in Italy or San Francisco? If you are a wafer thin crust lover of pizzas that melt in your mouth then put this on your list of places to visit. Very authentic Italian. Tiny place that deserves a big shout out.  5 stars baby!
author: Todd G.

description:
It's been more than ten years since I lived in Italy and it's places like this that make me happy that if I can't live in Italy, at least I'm close to this place.

I have been making a very deliberate tour of North Beach and no matter how many times I walk around, I always come here for lunch.  My favorite is the tuna panino with impossibly thin foccacia, mayo, capers and something...sorta spicy.  I love these people - they UNDERSTAND the Italian left inside of me, and nurse it back to health.  The cookies are divine and so is everything else I've tried.

But I come back, again and again, for the tuna panino.
author: Andrea M.

description:
I Love Danilo. I love the fact that I can wake up in the morning and take my dog for a little walk down the block and pick up a fresh, small loaf of bread for 85 cents and a cuppa joe and then have it for breakfast. This place is truly and genuinely Italian. Their pizzas and sandwiches are excellent. The atmosphere is excellent. And they are always friendly. And most importantly, they love my dog. 
You just can't ask for more.
author: Carla P.

description: Awesome!  Went to Italy last summer and have been on a thin crust quest since.  If you want authentic Roma style Italian pizza, Cafe Baonecci has it!!!  Plus, the family that owns the shop is totally cool and they've decorated like a real Italian restaurant in Rome.  They have always given us excellent service.
author: Brian P.

description:
BaoNecci's foccacia is thin, has a light crust and soft middle, and most importantly IS NOT DRENCHED IN OIL (don't worry it still has great flavor).  It makes for a fantastic panini.  I had crisp fresh veggies in mine, and am guessing it was made the same day.

The other food there looks promising.  There was a group enjoying a great looking thin-crust pizza with thin-sliced pears/prosciutto? (may have been Focaccina Ripiena or Contadina).

The cafe has that small, local quality typical of North Beach.  It's a nice place to stop by during a stroll in the neighborhood, but don't expect anything fancy.

Btw, decent prices!
Veggie Panini $6.95
author: Christina J.

description:
My dream has come true, Bao Neci is now open for dinner!! This is the only pizza that I respect and love in this city.

Where in North Beach, or all of San Francisco can you find the owners making the food-who are actually from Italy? And with all of their heart? 

Simple menu but 100% authentic, good quality ingredients, and super friendly family owned establishment.

The lasagna is home made and delicious...pizza con cotto e funghi-delectible!!!

San Francisco is fortunate to have Bao Neci.
author: Petra J.

description: I couldn't love this place anymore.  Quaint and cozy. The owners two cute sons act as if you are part of the family. It would be hard to fake the genuine warmth they showed. Food was over the top delicious. And to top it all off, I dropped my sweater outside when I was leaving. One of the cute sons ran two blocks to find me and return it! Seriously. Sometimes five stars just aren't enough;)
author: Jenny J.

description: Excellent pizza, warm atmosphere, wonderful family-owned and operated!
author: Clifford C.

description: Solid family run pizza place. As a bonus you get to walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom :)
author: Jessie O.

description:
thinnest pizza ever! we loved this local, quiet, family-owned and run restaurant. you can see the family eating and working here. both sons are cuties. there were plenty of locals here too. tourists were a minority. we enjoyed a home-made ceasar salad (that was a little short on dressing but they brought it over to us) and one of the pizzas. one bite of the sausage and pepperoni and I was ready to order my 2nd pizza but the girls stopped me since we were constantly eating. pizza is a little small and pricey at $16 but we were on vacation and we pay with our stomachs not brains.
cost for 1 pizza, 2 cokes, a salad and some yummy mini pastries =$35. no fancy decor and eating pizza in north beach with Italians and great service =priceless.
author: Tiana F.

description: Quaint, small Italian cafe in North Beach with coffee, cookies, pastries, focaccia, pizzas, and paninis.  I wish their coffee selection was larger, even though Danilo's selection is probably the norm in Italy.  I'm just not a coffee drinker, so I prefer the creamier, sweeter concoctions, which they don't offer.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
We had a great lunch here. The soup of the day was really good, warming, filling and simple. The focaccia sandwich was quite tasty. The focaccia was thinly slice, crispy, and not the least bit oily.
We got some cookies and pastries to go.  Also very good. Looking forward to returning and trying some pizza.
author: Margie L.

description: I visited this afternoon and fell in love with this beautiful family and this incredibly charming spot.  Simply the most authentic experience of Italian atmosphere and hospitality you will ever have outside of Italy.
author: Aeryn J.

description:
pretty solid joint

apps: 
my bro had a goat cheese salad and loved it

I had the killer farro/bean soup with a killer flatbread 

pizza:
we shared a mush/arugula pizza which the flavor was very good... but this is critical the pizza coulda been hotter and crisper. pretty standard in Rome but still not the holy father blessing it, get it? 

I'm going back. 

the service was perfect (lunch on weekday)

so there you go. a solid choice in North Beach, SF
author: Nik D.

description:
Wonderful, welcoming staff (the owners) who seem to have just arrived from Italy. The pizza is the only thing I have there so I can only speak to that: it is in the top 3 pizzas in San Francisco, if you like thin crust. Try any vegetarian pizza and you will be glad.

When they get their liquor license, I will change my rating to 5 stars :-)
author: Boris R.

description:
When I moved to North Beach a year ago, this was the first place that I ate, and I continue to come back regularly because it's the best damn pizza in North Beach. Other places are great for a slice, but if you want a sit down meal, BaoNecci is your spot.

The setting is casual and the restaurant is run by a tatted-up Italian family. The service is excellent, and I've never been disappointed with the food.

That said, pizza is their specialty. Get the pizza contadina (pear and bleu cheese); you won't regret it.
author: Samantha B.

description:
My friends and I are walking along North Beach trying to find a good, cheap place to eat when we came across Cafe Baonecci. We said, "Hey, why not?" We ordered two pizzas and ate it. 

The pizzas: Very light and delicious. Even after 4 slices per person, we didn't feel bloated. Some pizzas have the effect of making you feel like a glutton after eating it, but we felt good after eating the pizzas here.

The atmosphere: You can tell it's a family-owned place. The people are nice and the atmosphere was just warming.

Overall, the place is indeed cheap and a good place for weary travelers who are looking for delicious food that won't break the bank.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Finally tried Caffe BaoNecci and was very pleased.  The decor was sweet and it felt like being in your nonna's home...the relaxation begins.  The burrata salad with its fresh cheese, arugula and the warm, cannellini bean salad were delicious. Next we had the pepperoni & sausage pizza - oh...this crust is divine and the meats not salty...YUM!
We had to try a pasta dish and had the puttanesca sauce with rigatoni and while this is different from what I am used to it was still great in its simple preparation.
We brought a little of everything home with us so I could try a cannoli and it was fantastic - decadent, but not overly sweet which allowed the fresh ricotta to stand up and take a bow.  The service was impeccable and helpful.  We were thanked several times and made to feel very welcome.  I cannot wait to come back and feel the hug of a dear nonna like Caffe BaoNecci. Grazie!
author: Suzanne N.

description:
I don't know if it is the same one reviewed on Yelp under Danilo Bakery's BaoNecci, at 516 Green, the food in the pictures look the same, but the pictures of the inside of the restaurant look totally different.  Address is super close though, so who knows!???

Anyways, regardless, authentic, quaint cute little place, with pizza by the slice, panini sandwiches, and tons of pastries.  Maybe 4-5 tables inside and 4-5 tables outside!  The foccacia panini sandwich was a huge serving and the sandwich itself was paper thin with just enough of everything for flavor but not too much where you feel like you have to roll out of the joint.  

I imagine sitting outside here on a hot sunny day on a weekend in North Beach would be the perfect thing to do here  but on the days that I have been here, I'm always rushing about!  

Will be back though to sit and veg and people watch.
author: Denise B.

description:
Oh, oh, oh, I cannot say nearly enough good things about Caffe Baonecci. 

The pizza haunts my dreams, in a good way.  In a very, very good way. I may or may not be developing an addiction. Don't judge me.

The service is fantastic--always polite, friendly, and prompt. They make everyone feel like a regular.

The atmosphere is casual and charming. Red checkered table cloths and little white lights all round. Very simple but sweet.
author: Tatiana T.

description: Pear pizza is amazing. Had good wine. Took client from out of town. They loved it. Can be noisy. Not romantic. Festive. We'll keep returning.
author: Deborah R.

description:
So authentic, so good. Their made to order pizzas taste like in Italy, definitely worth a little drive to get this unbelievably thin chunk of awesomeness.

And they're super cool too.
author: Guillaume R.

description: My husband and I came here for lunch today and ordered the marinara marocchi pizza.  OMG.  So delicious.  We're on our "day off" on the 4 hour diet, so we were just going to split one pizza and then scamper around North Beach, stuffing ourselves with lots of other yummy Italian food.  But you know what?  That marinara marocchi pizza was so ridiculously scrumptious good that we ordered another one.  Which was just as good.  We'll be back, that's for sure!
author: Heather C.

description:
A family-owned restaurant run by Italians from the Lucca area.
Pizza's are as authentic as you would find in Lucca. 
Unusual ingredients, i.e. Curled up pear slices and gorgonzola and
great mozzarella. We found their pizzas to be very good. They even
make a dessert pizza with fruit and cheese. The pizza is very thin
but all are very tasty. The place itself was an old bakery, and is very plain.
They also have some Italian dishes. They try hard to please, and I would recommend this place.
author: Girly Foodie F.

description:
I had almost given up on finding this place, but I'm glad I walked up the block. Tiny hole in the wall, but when I went in and saw the different dishes, I knew it would be good.

I ordered a panini, I think called "Il Studente" and it was really great. Staff is friendly and they have yummy baked goods. It's kind of a pain to get to (at least from where I'm staying), but if in Northbeach, try this! 

Total bill (with tax) for panini and some baked goods: 8.50?
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Great food, friendly service (but slow), nice location. It's pretty small and the selection of eats was somewhat limited.

There are more upscale ($$$$$) places on Columbus, and there are a few other holes in the wall along Green St. on the same block. I heard someone walking down the street raving about a place half a block away. But I wasn't unhappy with my pizza or my nice warm latte on a chilly day, nor was my table on the sidewalk a terrible place to sit.

If you're looking for low priced lunchy stuff, this is a home run. If you want a fancy upscale place, or a wacky pizza centric joint, keep walking, it's probably 1-2 blocks away.
author: Jamie F.

description: Very good pizza. Great people watching. The locals were entertaining and the staff was warm and welcoming.
author: B D.

description: Small, low-key Italian family run restaurant. Father, Mother and Son (at least who we met) serve delicious very thin crust pizza, a fantastic burrata (imported) salad and some other lovely dishes. The cannolo was so delicious in its simplicity with the ricotta filling being the highlight. BaoNecci is definitely a breath of fresh air for its authenticity and small Italian charm amongst the other busy and crowded restaurants in the area. Ciao Elia!
author: Vanessa C.

description: The pizza is pretty good if you are a super thin crust fan. The atmosphere feels great. We also had melon and prosciutto, which didn't feel super fresh.  The wine was "meh" too...
author: Laurent T.

description:
After living in North Beach for a year and a half, I finally decided to try "some of the neighborhood secrets" one day when I had the day off from work, Memorial Day, I think.  

I never was a coffee person, but they made the best flippin cappucino I ever had!  Must be some "real" italian technique.

It was really special to be in one of SF's "old world" places, where Italian women wearing babushkas come in to pick up their bread orders, speaking only Italian.

Their pastries and pizzas look great.  I'll be back to this neighborhood gem again to try.
author: Max G.

description:
Out of curiosity, I asked our waiter what the name of the place meant.  In an Italian accent that so perfectly fit, he replied that it was slang from his hometown for 'groovy cafe'

Although i'm usually a deep dish pizza kind of guy, this place had such good reviews that i just had to try.  i went with a friend and we asked our waiter what he would recommend. He suggested the Monte Blanco without hesitation and with such conviction that we got that and after a little bit of deliberation, got a margherita pizza too.  Both were soooooo good... so so good.  And the fact that the crusts are so thin makes it easier to eat without getting ridiculously full!  I wish I remembered the waiter's name, but we also went with his suggestion for dessert: chocolate tartufo.  Mmmmm... groovy cafe has some damn good food!
author: Hyle P.

description:
Several months back, i was at north beach with two housemates, looking for pizza. Tommaso came to mind, but it was too packed and therefore we turned to our trusty yelp apps. It led us to this place, tucked into a quiet street. 

First of all, nice interior with checkered table cloths and a bar at the end. Seems to be run by a family, and they were all very friendly and we were sat down quickly.
 
On to food. The pizza was perfect in every way. The amount of ingredients, the crust, the size of the pie, everything. Ingredients were very fresh, especially the cheese. With quality like this, I'm sure every pizza on the menu is very good. The price i felt were fair for the quality and satisfying portion size. 

I haven't returned yet, but it's still definitely on my mind as one of my favorite places to eat in SF.
author: Jim Y.

description:
My wife's a pizza "snob" from the land of Pepe's and Sally's... (New Haven, CT).  Over the years we have had countless hours of discussion regarding the merits of sauce, crust, veggies, cheese quality, etc.

We have made a wonderful exploration of the U.S. looking for great pizza joints while traveling...  Truthfully, we are mostly hooked on Neapolitan style pizza.  

After moving to SF, we've had limited breakthrough experiences on the pizza front.  

She LOVES BaoNecci!  Thin crispy crust, great tomato sauce with San Marzano tomatoes... I'm already hungry thinking about it.  Elia is great... super attentive and patient with our questions.  He seems genuinely delighted when we rave about the food.

Ambience is okay and the wine choices have been poor at best.  Wish parking were not such a bear... BUT we will return religiously for the pizza.  After all, "Happy wife, happy life!"
author: Karthik V.

description: The funghi pizza with thin crust is very good.  The drinks are also pretty good, and reasonably priced ($6 for a bellini).
author: Niniane W.

description: Best pizza in San Francisco hands down if you're looking for that authentic Roman pizza experience. Thin, flaky crusty with a variety of fresh toppings - go for the mozzarella, prosciutto, and arugula for the real deal. Run by a friendly Italian family. Decor is of the checkered tablecloth variety - perfect for any occasion. A must try.
author: Greg B.

description:
My husband and I went to this restaurant after reading the great reviews and when we got to this place I was a little bit hesitant to try it as it was empty. 
My husband convinced me to go and I am glad I listened to him! Everything was delicious! 
I am not a desert person but after a delicious meal we decided get a couple of them from the menu and they were the best!
We will definitely go back.
author: Viviana A.

description:
Visited on sun 5/24 in a search of another place. The food was awesome, atmosphere cozy and it felt like family. The owner made kick-ass cappuccino, one of the best I ever had.  Wife had ravioli and I munched on the soup of the day with a piece of bread. 

Highly recommend 

By the way they are called now BaoNecci
author: J D.

description: Excellent thin crust pizza! Staff was attentive and charming. Busy but small place.
author: Mignon H.

description:
You feel like you are in Italy in this small neighborhood bakery. We only discovered the place recently and it's a favorite place to go when we are in North Beach.
The couple that run the place really care about what they are serving. Everything we have tried is delicious, the foccaccia, pizza and pastries. Last time we were there, we got a complimentary rice, donut thingy that was absolutely great. Even though Italian is the main language spoken (the wife speaks English), it's all delicious in any language! To top it off, they make really good espresso, better than we've found elsewhere in the city. A great place to hang out on a sunny weekend afternoon and just take in the atmosphere of an authentic Italian place with great food.
author: Louise O.

description: Thinnest pizza in the city, that's for sure. So thin that the crust breaks off like you're eating sun chips. We started off with the charcuterie plate. Who knew that a plate of salami, prosciutto, olives and cheese could be so bland. I was a bit dissapointed at our starter but looked forward to the pizza.  We ordered the Napoletana pizza with anchovies and capers. The highlight here was the San Marzano tomato sauce as it  (combined with the overbearing Italian discourse in the background) hinted at the authenticity of this pizza shop. I've had better thin crust pizza and I think Tomassos pizza (a few blocks away) tastes better. However, this place is family owned, a bit quentin tarantinoesque (always good) and serves  fresh Napolitan style pizza.
author: Annie Y.

description: Pizza is good, but very expensive for serving size. Great customer service though. But honestly, Golden Boy pizza is right down the block, its just as good and you get more for your money.
author: Ashley C.

description: Came for dinner at 6:30 on a Wednesday. The place was maybe a third full and we had none of the service issues mentioned in other reviews. Pizza was fabulous and waiters quite friendly and helpful.
author: Kirke C.

description: We were vacationing in SF and looked in yelp for some suggestions for dinner. The reviews and pictures look mouthwatering! After walking a mile here we were turned away because we did not have a reservation at 8:30 on a Monday night! They asked how many in my party, we are 2 toddlers and 2 adults. The hostess paused and asked if I had reservation while there were two open tables of 4 right at the front door! So disappointed and angry!
author: Tina B.

description:
Love Love Love

Pro's
*Great coffee, pastries, and pizza
*Friendly baristas-cute
*Get the feeling of being in Europe..lots of diversity amongst the patrons
*When the sun is shining sitting outside is perfect
*Quiet and away from busy Colombus St 

Go early, Go late, read a book , complete a crossword puzzle, relax, Enjoy
author: Alexandrea R.

description: My boyfriend and I came here because of Yelp. I have to say: Amazing! I had this pear pizza (can't remember Italian name). It was beautiful! Excellent presentation. It looked like a fluffy flower was laid on the pizza when in fact it was the pear cut into a long spiral. My boyfriend has the chicken parmigiana and he was blown away. The chicken was cooked perfectly tender. The staff was also very knowledgeable about their wines and even offered samples. Coming back here on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Roz M.

description: Great service. Great location. But most of all great food. Highly recommend the Monte bianco or classic pepperoni. Service was quick and great. Great for lunch.
author: Irma S.

description: Certainly one of the best pizzas I've ever had, and such a cool little place!  Not pretentious at all, with a couple of genuine Italian gents sipping their espresso in the corner while reading the Gazetto.  They could make this place into such a moneyspinner, but instead they're keeping it real.  Awesome!
author: Foster K.

description: Lovely family owned restaurant.  Monte Bianco with scoop of mascarpone cheese is delicious.
author: around town e.

description: I used to think of North Beach as the land of bad tourist traps and strip joints, but have been slowly finding gems that make this neighborhood a true Little Italy.  This is definitely one of those gems.  The atmosphere is unassuming and barren, but many of the clientele seem to be direct from Italy.   We had the pear salad and the parma prociutto pizza with mushrooms.  The salad was good and simple.  The pizza was thin as a cracker the way i like it.   : )  The toppings were fresh, thinly layered and perfect.  Was so yummy.  If I lived closer and it wasn't a tad pricey, I'd be here all the time.
author: beverly l.

description: A totally unassuming restaurant serving excellent pizza. We were able to walk in on a Sunday for lunch and were seated immediately. The waiter didn't fuss over us at all which was fine as we were able to enjoy the delicious thin crust pizza leisurely. One thing to consider is there eggplant parmigiana which was easily as tasty as the pizza themselves. Definitely a worthy competitor to the zillion pizza restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Procter F.

description:
Every so often I have a mozzerella and tomato sandwich on focaccia at Cafe Greco. But I hate to order what I can make at home (and unfortunately, much to my husband's chagrin, I can and do love to make most things you can get on a restaurant menu).

So one day I asked Greco where they get their focaccia. At Danilo they say.  Well heck, that's just a couple of blocks from my place!  So on Friday afternoon I walk over and inquire about the focaccia.  Can I get some? Oh sure, I can.  FOR TWENTY DOLLARS A SHEET.  Holy crap!
I was embarrassed to voice my dismay (hey, I'm on a student's budget). Um, can I get half?  Yes.  

Half made about six sandwiches, so not bad.  But not as good as if I'd  made the bread myself, which I will do next time.

The sad part was the ten dollar bread was overbaked way, WAY browner than I like my bread.  Of course, the one time I throw down a ten spot for a damn loaf of bread I'm going to get a burned piece.  However, I know the bread is good because I have it often at Greco.

This bread is delicious. But be prepared to be a little sore on your way out the door.
author: Jamie C.

description: The best authentic Italian thin-crust pizza in San Francisco. I've gone here with some hard-core European foodies and they confirm my opinion - this is the real stuff. Very good food, reasonable prices, and family run...can you tell I like this place?
author: Josiah M.

description:
One of my favorite North Beach stops.  Feels like you stepped about 40 years back in time.  Their Italian Wedding Cookies are the best I've had.  A great place to practice your Italian as well.

UPDATE 12/7/07:

Since the ownership has changed, so have the wedding cookies.  I don't like them as much, but that's okay.  This place is still a North Beach gem.   It still feels like Italia in here.
author: Val U.

description: Absolutely delicious! Thin crust pizza only made possible with a super hot oven, excellent seasonings and a lot of love.
author: Jen N.

description: The Best!  Authentic food.  Cute place!  Elia and Paolo are the best!  Love them!  GREAT food!
author: John K.

description: Good pizza and quick service.  Especially for a Friday night!!  A little pricy for size but it reminds me of pizza in Italy!
author: RJ P.

description:
I'm so happy this place changed hands!  It used to be really dark with papered windows and limited goods.  

Now it is GORGEOUS!  

The paper is gone and sun streams into the windows overlooking a flower (albeit polyester) framed outdoor seating area. It's a friendly family atmosphere complete with photos of Neighborhood folks lining the walls.  They make their own bread and pizzas among other yummy lunchtime goodies like foccacia panini and biscotti bigger than my nonno's thumbs (he had BIG thumbs).  

We needed a place that actually makes stuff and doesn't just truck it in from Costo or Dianda's.  Danilo's you answered our prayers!
author: Genevra P.

description: So very yummy.  On holiday in SF and wanted some warm pasta.  Found this little place off the beaten path.  We didn't have a reservations but they were able to accomdate my nine year old son, my  husband and myself who are all vegetarians.  As all kids my son loves pizza and this pizza was perfect. He continues to rave about the perfectly cooked thin crust. I had the pasta in pesto which was delish.  The service was wonderful and actually Italian!  Will return if we go back to S.F.
author: Myrna L.

description: Very lovely pizza! The thin cracker-like crust was delicious and the tomato sauce lightly spiced, just enough flavor and no sog! The prosciutto and arugula version had paper thin meat slices and wonderfully fresh greens with a nice peppery bite. The caprese salad was nicely done and even though it isn't tomato season, these were just fine (not stunning summer tomatoes, but acceptable). The dessert was absolutely delicious (espresso tartufo) and beautifully presented in a demitasse cup.
author: Roberta B.

description: Not a large selection, but what they have is delicious and very traditional italian. THIS IS NOT PIZZA HUT! Minimum seating, this is more aplaceyu take a first date to sho your kinda classy... if you can find parking.
author: Bobby B.

description: Delicious. A really cute location with delicious food. Lovely atmosphere  Nice staff and only a short wait on a Friday night.
author: Kim W.

description:
On many occasions I had the pleasure to experience the bounty, simplicity and outstanding taste of a Gambaccini family home cooked meal.
On one occasion I tasted a simple but excellent zuppa di farro (bean soup), fresh ravioli with homemade pesto and finished off with a Bindi gelato al tartufo and a good espresso with great crema.
I was born and raised in Rome, Italy so I am a little wary and always pay special attention to the details of the Italian venues I choose to eat at.
I fly for work into many cities both domestic and international and at one point or another I always look for a family owned Italian restaurant, trattoria or caffe'. 
Well, it is extremely rare to find the whole family involved in all areas of operation with mamma and, sometimes, papa' literally being the only ones who actually do the cooking and often also the ones who bring it to the table!
Most often, places get too big, or expand, or cater too vehemently to the Italian-american community and lose the spirit of the modern and original italian flavours.
In my opinion if you are in the Columbus Ave./Little Italy area and are looking for that italian spot a little off the beaten path look no further.
Also excellent place for authentic italian cornetto (croissant but NOT the regular overly-buttery one) and real cappuccino (unlike those served in humongous foam cups with huge bubbles on top)
E invito tutti gli italiani che per turismo o lavoro dovessero capitare dalle parti di Columbus Ave. (e immagino non siano in pochi) ad andare a trovare la famiglia gambaccini, non ve ne pentirete.
La loro disponibilita', la qualita' del servizio e del cibo e quel senso dell'umorismo tipico dei toscani vi faranno sentire a casa vostra.
Bravi Walter, Stefania e non dimentichiamoci di Elia e Filippo..
Ciao a tutti 
Marco
author: Marco N.

description: I don't want to sound pretentious, but I'm married to an Italian (from Italy) and I have had many amazing pizzas in Italy. This place is probably the closest thing you can get to Roman style pizza. The crust is cracker thin and crispy and the topping options are authentic. I think the portions are perfect, not too big and not too small. For those of you who don't know,  you are supposed to eat one pizza per person, that's how the Italians do it in Italy. Don't worry, you won't look like your being a pig for eating the whole thing.
author: Thy P.

description: One of the best pizza places in SF I've ever eaten. The taste was actually very close to the authentic one in Italy. The service was the part I didn't like much. But well, I went in for pizza, and got what I wanted.
author: Nitta P. B.

description:
Authentic Sicilian cafe in Little Italy/North Beach.  The man at the counter has a very thick Italian accent.  The woman in the kitchen spoke only in Italian.  Other customer conversations wove in and out of Italian, French and English.  Fun Mediterranean ambiance in the colors and textures. 

Great espresso. Excellent omelet.  Eggs were flat not puffy, maybe this is "Italian-style"? I don't know, but it's such a minor point it will not take this place down to four stars. The filling-Italian ham and mozzarella--was wonderful.  Possibly the best biscotti I've every had. 

Service was friendly and casual.  Also, this place opens early (8 am) on Saturday, when many other "breakfast" restaurants do not. 

Yes, it's a little expensive.  We had two biscotti, two lattes, an omelet, a croissant, and several petits four secs for about $20.  But it was worth it!
author: Julian H.

description: Wonderful experience.  The pear gorgonzola pizza is a work of art and melts in your mouth.  We also ordered the cheese plate and lemon sorbet - all delicious and beautifully presented.
author: Jaime S.

description:
I just had the pleasure of eating at Caffe BaoNecci for dinner.  I'm from out of town, but it was my second time here in the past three months.  I travel to San Francisco frequently on business and sort of stumbled on this tiny restaurant on my last visit.

Simply put, this is the best pizza I have had outside of Italy.  It's a crispy thin crust and it's all homemade.  I'm Italian and eating at Caffe BaoNecci is like eating in my grandmother's kitchen.  Not only is the food fantastic, but the staff is great too.  Most of them are Italian and I mean really Italian . . they speak it to one another.  Hard to find a place like that these days, especially in North Beach.  The owner, Walter, is extremely friendly and happy to chat with you about the history of his restaurant. 

It may not be the cheapest place in town, but it's worth every penny.  If you want a true experience and not just another ho-hum meal, check this place out.  I will return as often as I can.  Ciao!
author: John M.

description:
I like those sandwiches made with the round flat focaccia sprinkled generously with salt, mushrooms, cheese and ham.  Then they made it even better by smooshing it in a panini press.  

I heart panini.  Something about heating it all up within 2 hot grills until it's all melty and fantastic.  The caffe latte was good too.  Again, I happened to have ordered it on the hottest day of the weekend.

Cute little cafe.  A little out of the way for me.  But decent enough study spot too.

My mission these next weeks is to find proper/appropriate study spots where the owners/workers are ok with a few law students breaking out their textbooks and reading cases for a few hours.  Honestly, we don't make much of a mess and we're house broken.
author: Christina C.

description:
Absolutely fantastic pizza. Thinnest of crusts. The red sauce is superb...so delicious. 

The caprese salad is fantastic. 

The cannoli was unexpected, almost more savory than sweet. A very pleasant surprise to what I have had in NY. 

Very quaint, family pizzeria. We had Italians at 3 of 4 tables around us...some street cred. 

Only downside is that the wine list is terrible. By the glasss selections are cheap and pedestrain...do not stand up to the quality of the food. I love Italian wine and would love some fantastic reds to go with this top notch pizza. Maybe can bring in a bottle for a corkage fee next time....will have to check.
author: Patrick M.

description: Simple, Low-key ... with no compromise on quality. Don't go there if you are looking for an in-your-face experience though.
author: Pierre R.

description: The food is wonderful. Family run by a very accommodating (if slightly stressed) family. My wife, kids (10 and 6), and I loved the pizza, salad, pasta and bread.
author: Ken C.

description: Delicious and authentic!  I haven't had pizza like this since I was in Europe.  Sure, they're pricey, but when you're craving that certain delicate Italian pizza crust, it's totally worth it.
author: Kathryn L.

description: WOW! If only I could give this place 10 stars! The best pizza I've ever had! If you like thin crust this is the place for you, also try the delicious pear salad.
author: Denise J.

description:
Hunting for fresh focaccia after Liguria Bakery ended up being closed, my boyfriend and I wandered over to BaoNecci, and we're glad we did.  Upon entering, I was impressed with the selection of foods available.  They had a whole display case full of biscotti, as well as several trays of fresh focaccia sheets in different varieties, focaccia paninis, and a few by-the-slice thin crust pizzas.  The cafe also sells Italian import products (such as de Cecco pasta and Sanpellegrino sodas).

We decided to get two focaccia paninis--one prosciutto and mozzarella and one ham, mushroom, and mozzarella.  The server heated them for us and brought them out to us when they were ready.  They were so tasty, and they were also large.  The focaccia was a little crispy, having been reheated, but it had a fresh, buttery taste.  We were both quite satisfied.

I also really liked the atmosphere--cute, authentic little Italian cafe nestled on one of the side streets of North Beach.  When we walked in, we walked into an Italian conversation, and heard Italian rap music coming from the television.  The server (one of the members of the family that owns the restaurant) was very nice, and was very patient with our own Italian.  The place is cozy (maybe 5 or 6 little tables and 1 or 2 outside) and maybe not the least expensive place in the area, but it was definitely worth it!
author: Katrina S.

description:
Went here with my cousin Shawn who raved about this place and i have to say he was spot on.  The pizza is so authentic it took me back to eating in Florence. 

Purely family owned and they do a fantastic job.  Like Shawn said in his review, the food speaks for itself.

I will definitely be back here!
author: Vincent R.

description:
Practically every American has eaten pizza before, but NOT EVERYONE has eaten a pizza like Caffe BaoNecci's. We ordered the contadina pizza and lasagna. Both were superb in presentation and taste.

The contadina pizza is a three-cheese pizza topped with paper-thin slices of pear. Personally, I've never eaten pizza with a dough like BaoNecci's and must say that it was a nice change from the ordinary. I was very impressed by fruit on a pizza. Who would of thunk it? The pears tasted so well on the pizza that it inspired me to cut up apple slices on my own pizza.

Their lasagna was extraordinary. Not greasy at all and I did not feel bloated afterwards. I highly recommend it.

I was also impressed by the authentic Italian vibe from the restaurant. The menu briefly describes about the history of the family restaurant and why they carry only two types of wine. The American and Italian flag are hung above the ceiling and several portraits of Italians can be seen on the walls. Last but not least, the tables and chairs along with everything mentioned above make you feel like you're in a cafe in Italy. Seriously.

If I could give this more than 5 stars, I would. Next time you're sightseeing San Francisco, make sure to check out this gem of a restaurant.
author: Marc H.

description: By far some of the best pizza I have ever had. I am a big fan of thin-crust, and this is the ultimate. I ordered the Margherita (as per other reviews on Yelp) and was not disappointed. The atmosphere was pure Italian, with soccer playing on the big screen and a mix of locals with the after-church crowd. Will definitely be going back when I return to SF.
author: Lauren R.

description: I would have given it one, but the food was decent. We had the tomato caprese salad. It was bland and we had to add salt and pepper. BUT The cannellini bean soup was really good, and the pizza was tasty, but the service sucked! The servers hardly spoke a word except a brief nod or response when ordering. It was really busy, but we waited 15 mins in the cold san fran breeze for a table because of the good reviews on yelp. There seems to be no designated host, and no direction on whether to seat yourself or wait to be seated. We finally sat ourselves after never being acknowledged during our 15 min wait. The big screen TV was showing very provocative nude music videos, which was not at all appropriate. I would not return to this place. You can get better pizza and atmosphere elsewhere.
author: Vanessa G.

description: Not just the thinnest pizza in North Beach, but arguably the best. Stefania and Walter and their two sons run a delightful restaurant. You will not be disappointed at Bao Necci. And the movie nights are really fun, too, but mostly it's about their delicious, amazing pizza. Mille Grazie!
author: Stephanie S.

description: Came with two friends before heading to a show at the Fox in Oakland on a Tuesday night. Its a cozy little place, with an eclectic assortment of Italian themed art on the wall and everyone that works there has an Italian accent, very authentic feeling. We brought our own wine and ordered food to share: a salad (arugula, pear, and goat cheese) and two pizzas, one with prosciutto and arugula and the other with cheese and mushrooms (I know there were two with mushrooms and cheese on the menu but I forget which one we ended up getting). The salad was good, but I wished it was bigger since it was shared three ways. Both pizzas were delicious, with the definite winner being the prosciutto and arugula; none of us usually eat red meat but this was sooo worth it. We wanted a light meal because we were going to be dancing, and pizza is not generally this type of meal, but we all left perfectly satisfied but not weighed down. Great! Also our server was attentive and friendly (plus handsome, with those blue eyes and accent, mmm!) I'd definitely come back to this place!
author: Lindsey K.

description: Came here for Italian Movie night, which is the second Thursday night of each month. For $30 per person, you get a glass of prosecco, salad, appy, soup, and a main entree of their choosing. "Excellente!!" I shouted at the top of my lungs as I dove into their offerings. The tuscan bean soup was so fabulosa!! Then we got four different, paper thin pizzas, all of them so amazing, and served piping hot. Their pear pizza was so delectable. Great venue for ambiance, with very attentive wait staff, and I left giving everybody an italiano kiss, including the owners!
author: Mary M.

description: Probably my favorite place in all San Francisco.  Stefania makes the best pizza I've ever had outside of Italy (and, yes, I'm including my Brooklyn favorites Di Fara's, Franny's, and Lucali on that list).
author: John M.

description: Everything you would hope for in an authentic pizza place. Awesome thin crust pizza. Nice staff. Cozy, family owned pizza restaurant that more than lives up to its reviews. Btw....their chocolate ice-cream dessert creation is to die for.
author: Carolyn K.

description: Fantastic thin crust pizza!  The salads and bruschetta are delicious.  The staff are very friendly.  We thought the service was great too.  I can see why the place is so popular.
author: Jennifer P.

description: I'm not sure where the 1 $ rating came from.  This place is a rip off.  $16 for a medium pizza where the crust is paper thin and the toppings are scarce?  $7 for a salad so small that it would qualify as a side salad? I would understand (or at least expect) the high prices if this place was in an upscale neighborhood, but a hole in the wall in north beach?  And to make matters worse, we got charged a 20% service charge for a sunday lunch. Granted, we were a party of 9, but again, this was just lunch at a hole in the wall in North Beach.  Bottom line: yes, food is pretty good, but expect to spend a good $15 - $20/person to get properly fed.  Oh, and of course, this being North Beach, street parking is impossible, so expect to fork out another $11 for parking.
author: Julie H.

description:
Came here during North Beach festival.  I am definitely impressed with the food!!

Me and 2 friends got the Buffalo Margherita and the Porcini Mushroom pizza.  The sauce on both are amazing: sweet but not too sweet, not to tomato-y either.  The toppings fuse very well with the sauce and the crust.  Oh and the crust itself...it is thin and crunchy just to the right level, yum yum.

The only downside: the waiting system is not the most organize as they do not have a waiting list or buzzer but "wait in line" type.  The place is can also get crowded.  Just small grunges.
author: Arthur L.

description:
I loved the thin crust pizza I ordered there! It was the Mozzarella and basil pizza. I liked it because I ate all 7 slices and didn't feel overly stuffed but felt satisfied. Perfect serving 1 pizza per person. My Hubby had penne with marinara sauce which he loved. The atmosphere of this spot makes you feel like your in Italy. All the employees are Italian and so friendly. The food tasted homemade and very fresh , Yummy! 
Thank you BaoNecci for giving us exactly what we wanted and expected.
author: Rosie J.

description:
Delicious and beautiful, if simple and not-super-filling pizza. Delicious desserts (I had the chocolate gelato truffle, called tartufe?). Not crowded, not chic, not pretentious, not too expensive. Even though the pizza prices are not expensive, a large pizza won't fill up two hungry people, because the crust is so thin and airy.

I tend to dislike restaurants that have a television turned on, but in this case it was all Italian music videos without commercials, so it was not too disruptive.

Oh, and the people working there are very very kind.
author: Gary M.

description: Fantastic! We just asked the owner for his recommendations, and they were all excellent. Pretty small seating area. Cost was about $15 per entree, without drinks or tip (but with tax). We got 3 entrees for 4 ppl at lunch, just about the right amount of food.
author: Jim V.

description: The crust is beautiful!!! It's THE best pizza in the city, so not the usual thick overly-sauced, too much cheese, greasy pizzas you always get in America. The atmosphere is also lovely and the waiters are not smothering you but they actually let you enjoy your food! Oh and the tiramisu is also great.
author: Julie O.

description: I was here last month as recommended by a friend. The pizza and salads were off the hook. I will come back whenever I get to visit S.F. Plus the service was awesome!
author: Mike R.

description: Couldn't be more pleased with this remarkable dining experience tonight for my wife's birthday.  We could have eaten anywhere, and this was the perfect choice.  Thanks for the wonderful evening!
author: Jeff S.

description: I love you.  I love your thin, authentic Italian style pizza.  I love your Thursday movie night and all the cooky Franciscans I get to sit with at the communal table; we're all one, big dysfunctional family on Thursdays.  And, finally, I love you brother-sister waiter duo.  You guys are the cutest, especially when you kiss us all on both cheeks and speak to us in Italian, like we know what you're talking about.  I'm sure you're only saying nice things because we all have only nice things to say about this restaurant.  It's a gem.
author: Melissa M.

description: Wound up here in search of my favorite staple. My baseline is the Margherita, as it gives the crust no shelter. Caffe BaoNecci's did not disappoint.  In my opinion, if they can do this right, they can do it all. Time permitted only one visit, but I would return happily. Also liked the environs and staff a lot.
author: John D.

description: This place has the best pizza and calzones ever. The tomato sauce is perfection. It's light and flavorful. So good.
author: Carrie M.

description: We spend half of the year in pizza friendly NYC, when there we are there we are burrito-starved, and here in SF we are pizza-starved.That said, we have lived in North Beach for a dozen years, and the only pizza place that satisfies us is Tommasos, great flavor. Cafe Baonecci now the only other place we will get pizza in SF. They are 2 different pizzas, to suit different moods and cravings, and they are both excellent. This place reminds me 100% of the pizza I ate all over Rome and Naples, it is stellar and we will now be regulars, we will alternate between here and Tommasos going forward.
author: Camille g.

description: My husband & I recently married and stay close to Little Italy, So we decided to try out all the restaurants in the neighborhood. And we found this restaurant when we were walking down the street, looking for a place to dine. And we are in love with this place. We love the pizzas here!! Especially the Zucchini pizza it is the best thin crust pizza. The taste is amazing, I think it is because they use fresh ingredients. They have a lot of vegetarian options. The only downside is that most times you have to wait 20 minutes to get a table. But the food is so good that it's worth the wait :)
author: Anu R.

description: oh my.... i didn't realize I haven't reviewed this place yet! Their pizza is perfect. Just read everyone else's 5 star reviews. super thin crust - fired up quickly - so tasty & delicious! I've had a variety of toppings and was not disappointed at all and couldn't even really pick a favorite. They're super nice people. great food. great beverage options. yum yum yum.
author: lynn t.

description:
This was my first time eating at Caffe BaoNecci. The pizza was fantastic, I had the Cotto e Funghi, basically mushroom and prosciutto. The pizza was on a very thin crust and all the ingredients were very high quality. The pizza was very "light" feeling and didn't taste overly fatty. I will go here every opportunity I get (which admittedly won't be often, but still). 

If you don't like thin crust and lighter pizzas, this isn't for you.
author: Brian S.

description: Pizza was very overpriced, small, beyond thin and strange.  One of the pizza was thin crust but soft which is a bad combination.  The other was extremely thin and had the texture of a tortilla chip.  Overly stiff and crispy, didn't have cheese, barley any sauce, just garlic and ground chili peppers.  Pizzeria Regina in Boston is the best pizza by far and this pizza isn't even close.  I only came here because of the good ratings.  People, have you eaten pizza prior to this place?  Do you have any sense of what good pizza is and what is normal for portions and price?
author: Ben P.

description: It was Sunday and I was craving pasta but instead we ended up with pizza at Caffe BaoNecci - thanks to Yelp!  Amazing lunch - best thin crust pizza ever!  The family who runs this place is so great and everyone is so  friendly!  We had the yummy caprese salad to start, some meat lasagna, and the parma pizza.  Would soooo go back!
author: Bettina S.

description: Awesome little spot in North Beach. Went on the recommendation of others on Yelp. It's small an warm in the summer. Pizza is a must try. We also had a caesar salad which was great. This was lunch for us so didn't eat too much. Worth a try!
author: Percy K.

description: Decided to check this place out after seeing great reviews on Yelp when we were visiting in San Francisco. SO glad we did. Excellent service, great pizza and cool atmosphere. Definitely recommend it highly.
author: Frank C.

description: Had an okay experience here. The atmosphere was sweet but the service was poor and food okay. I won't list all the gripes here but I was very dissapointed. I plan to give it a second chance, to be continued...
author: M L.

description: Small restaurant, personal touch, terrific salads (in love with the Burratta salad), awesome pizza, and great service.  We loved the experience.  The servers seem to really care about your experience without being overbearing.  Pizza is completely different than your average pizza and that's definitely a good thing.  We will return again and again.
author: Josh H.

description:
I've been meaning to write a review on this place for sometime, however, it wasn't until a lackluster pizza experience in Denver that I've been motivated enough to get around to it.  

This place is AMAZING.  Our first night in the city, we had a craving for pizza and were lucky enough to find this place on yelp.  After trying to park for 30 minutes (I don't know why we thought a car in the city was a good idea?), we found our way in.  Actually, after parking, then reading parking signs for 10 minutes and asking locals (apparently no one owns a car) trying to figure out if it was okay to park where we did, we arrived, but that's a whole different story.  The dining room was small, with Italian TRL playing on a giant TV overlooking the dining room (apparently Italy LOVES their ballads).  We were greeted by our waiter, a younger handsome man, who I immediately ordered my girlfriend not to interact with (JOKING....kind of...no seriously, I'm kidding).  He helped us select a pizza and a salad.  The salad came out first and was delicious.  I can't recall the pizza we ordered, but do remember that it had green olives.  It was different than anything I'd ever had, but is now the standard by which I measure all thin crust pizza.  It's hard to explain exactly (especially as I'm writing this review a month later), but it had a fresh/nutritious quality about it.  After we had finished the pizza, we talked to our waiter for a bit, who told us a lot about himself and his family which owned the place.  He was a very charming guy and was constantly smiling (something that seems to be increasingly rare these days).  We decided to finish off dinner with a desert, and ordered a cannoli.  Which was, like everything else, delicious.  Before leaving, I had to use the bathroom, which you have to walk through the kitchen to access.  Although the experience was weird, I do respect that their kitchen is clean, albeit small (our waiter's mom was back there and had to turn sideways for there to be enough room for me to pass....I'm 170lbs, if you're envisioning a guy that normally requires people to stand sideways to pass, that's not me).  Anyway, I came out to my girlfriend exchanging numbers with our waiter and let them BOTH know what's what......KIDDING!  I ran out crying.
author: Pat A.

description: Stopped in for lunch last friday and was happy with the bite to eat. The minnestrone was very tasty, as well as the tuna panini my guy got. Very cute, family owned neighborhod joint. I loved all the pictures on the walls. There's a few tables outside so itd be a great place to get some coffee and treats and enjoy the sunshine on a nice day. I didn't get a chance to try any of the bakery treats but they all look really good. We'll definitely be back.
author: Audrey V.

description: The best pizza in San Francisco! Great beer and wine list.  Great service as well. I would recommend this place to anyone.
author: Alessandro G.

description: Comedically thin pizza! 2 pies for 5 people = $27, and we were still starving and wondering what we would eat for dinner after this appetizer.
author: Alex M.

description: WHAT A DISAPPOINTMENT!!!!!! My wife and I ordered the Pasta after the gentleman who works there told us it was thick, spicy and delicious. It tasted and I'm not exaggerating this, like it was straight out of a frickin CAN and at the prices they charge!!! Enough said!
author: Ian M.

description: Italian cafe at its best!  I found this place late on a Friday evening while wandering in SF on a business trip.  Was transported to Naples by both the food and ambiance.  Unpretentious and delicious.  Definitely on my must return to list.
author: Karen D.

description: ok, I am Italian and my husband surprised me with this little coffee place where you can find the Bindi cornetti like in Milan. Even if the briosche was obviously frozen it reminded me of Milan. We ordered capuccinos and brioches and went back for focaccia. After talking with the owner we thought he would serve us the real authentic thing. My husband had the prosciutto crudo focaccia. The focaccia was stale, what disappointment... I had the focaccia with brie and that was reheated so there was no way for me to understand if the focaccia was old. We had the pizza too and that seems to be fresh. Still why would you serve a stale focaccia that costs us 8$ without saying anything? I hope this was just a mistake but I am not sure If I'll go back again
author: Biemme B.

description: Hands down the best pizza in North Beach. Authentic, thin crust!! Fair prices. Family owned and operated. Great service! Love the Burrata and tomato salad. North Beach hidden gem. You will not be disappointed.
author: Leo C.

description: This place is awesome! I spent a summer in Italy a while back and ever since I have been on the hunt for good, uncomplicated espresso. The espresso here is fantastic. Strong, not bitter, smooth and creamy. The old man who helped me was also really friendly. The whole vibe was welcoming and family oriented. The biscotti are great, too. I tried an Anise flavored one. The cookie was softer than most conventional biscotti (you get at a coffee shop) and held up well when I dunked it. Can't wait to go back! For now, just dreaming about it
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Went here while on vacation, looking for tasty thin crust pizza, and thanks to Yelp, we selected BaoNecci.  It's a 10-table (I counted) cozy restaurant, with an attentive staff and VERY good pizza.  I had an all-meat pizza, my wife had the pear pizza talk about, and my sons had a caprese pizza and a salami pizza.  All were very good and distinctive - each flavor was distinguishable and the crust was thin but foldable, so I could finish my pizza and start in on my wife's leftovers!  I would definitely recommend one pizza per person, unless you have appetizers or a larger salad.  They are a little pricey too - ours were about $20 each, but we truly enjoyed the dining experience.  My only knock is that $4.75 for a CAN of Coke for my son seems a little excessive, and they charged me for two glasses of $11 chianti, when I only had one.  (Just discovered this on the receipt.)  It's definitely a great choice for flavorful, distinctive pizzas.
author: Lance T.

description: loved this place too...pasta so fresh...had the pesto mmmm.
author: Amanda J.

description: Great cookies here. The amaretto are my favorites and they charge by the pound. Do you know how much I'd be worth if I was a cookie?
author: Josua P.

description: Lots of different kind of cookies every where!!!! Love it. Behind the cookie counter are the wooden shelves of amazingly great smelly fresh bread. I love the yeasted Italian corn bread the most. The rounds of olive oily-foccacia that are scattered with course salt and rosemary, scallions, or tomato sauce is a close second. The atmosphere seems really relaxing and friendly.
author: Juliane N.

description: If you prefer the REAL Italian pizza to the thick American one go there! Una buonissima pizza Parma e dopo un buon caffè! A very nice cosy ambiente, not at all touristic (some in the area are).
author: Stephan M.

description: I haven't been here in ages but when my husband and I were dating I lived on telegraph hill and we used to go and get almond macaroons together. Thinking about this place reminds me of a sweet and simpler time. The macaroons are the only thing  that we ever got here, but they are some of the best in north beach. Watch out though for the old lady behind the counter because she will give you about three times the amount of cookies than you ask for and they sell them by the pound. The other good thing about this place is that you can order the macaroons soft and chewy or dry and crispy, most bakeries will be only one or the other. This is a hidden little jewel that most tourist walk right by without even noticing.
author: Esa Y.

description: Very average food.  Pizza crust is good for a thin and crispy, though it didn't have much flavor.  Toppings and sauce are just okay.  Skip the bruschetta and just get some fried bread and olive oil.   Did not satisfy my craving for pizza.  The search will continue...
author: Dee K.

description: After reading reviews I was excited to try this place out. Even left the few block area is usually stick to when I'm in town. I made a reservation on a Wed night. Walked in and 5-7 tables were open (half the restaurant). I was by myself and they clearly only wanted to sit me at the bar which I did not. Why I made reservation for a table. They made me stand at the door for 5 mins while the original greeter told another person who came up to me and we had the same conversation about not wanting to sit at bar. He then made me wait some more. Clearly half the restaurant was empty??? Why can't I sit down? Finally they sat me. The service was ok. Not bad but not great. Had to ask for bread and it was not buttered and yummy like another review mentioned. I got the Arriabiata pasta which is supposed to be spice and garlicky. It was just ok. A bit spicy but no true taste. It did appear to be run by real Italians however but my dish was disappointing. This along with them not wanting to serve me at a table results in a 3 star rating.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Checked this place out looking for an Italian restaurant NOT on Broadway or Columbus. Everything we ordered was delicious. The prosciutto and melon appetizer, the salad with pears and feta, the lasagna...but the pizza (arugula & porcini mushrooms) was PERFECT. The crust, perfectly cooked and perfectly thin; just the right amount of cheese and delicious sauce; fresh arugula; and melt-in-your-mouth mushrooms. DIVINE!!!
author: Chae P.

description: Got a table right away. Salad with pears and goat cheese was excellent, also a good size. Pizza and pastas were really good! it was a great, tasty, affordable family dinner to end our vacation on a good note.
author: Marisa R.

description: very good super thin pizza crust, salads were outstanding.  nice, casual atmosphere, authentic Italian owners from Lucca, Italy.
author: Eileen B.

description:
